APPENDIX. 


457 


ELECTION  DISTRICTS— as  established  by 
the  Commissioners  appointed  by  the  State  Legis- 
lature of  1856: 

First  District— Is  bounded  by  Kearny  Street 
on  the  west,  Pacific  Street  on  the  South  and  the 
Bay. 

Second  District— Is  bounded  by  Pacific  Street 
on  the  south,  the  Bay  on  the  north,  Leavenworth 
Street  on  the  west  and  Kearny  Street  on  the  east. 

Third  District— Is  bounded  by  Clay  Street  on 
the  south,  Pacific  Street  on  the  north,  Kearny 
Street  on  the  west  and  the  Bay  on  the  east. 

Fourth  District— Is  bounded  by  Clay  Street  on 
the  south,  Pacific  Street  on  the  north,  Larkin 
Street  on  the  west  and  Kearny  Street  on  the  east. 

Fifth  District — Is  bounded  by  Pine  Street  on  the 
south,  Clay  Street  on  the  north,  Kearny  Street 
on  the  west  and  the  Bay  on  the  east. 

Sixth  District— Is  bounded  on  the  south  by 
Pine  Street,  on  the  north  by  Clay  Street,  on  the 
west  by  Larkin  Street  and  on  the  east  by  Kearny 
Street. 

Seventh  District — Is  the  triangle  bounded  by 
Market,  Dupont  and  Pine  Streets. 

Eighth  District— Is  bounded  by  Market  Street 
on  the  south,  Pine  Street  on  the  north,  Larkin 
Street  on  the  west  and  Dupont  Street  on  the  east. 

Ninth  District — Is  the  triangle  bounded  by 
Second  Street,  Market  Street  and  the  Bay. 

Tenth  District — Is  bounded  by  the  Bay,  Har- 
ris (now  Seventh),  Market  and  Second  Streets. 

Eleventh  District — Is  an  irregular  space  com- 
mencing at  the  foot  of  Seventh  Street,  running 
along  Seventh  to  Market,  along  Market  to  Larkin, 
along  Larkin  to  Bush,  along  Bush  to  the  bounda- 
ry of  San  Mateo  county,  and  along  this  bounda- 
ry to  the  place  of  beginning. 

Twelfth  District — Is  bounded  by  Bush  Street 
on  the  south,  the  Bay  on  the  north,  the  bounda- 
ry of  San  Mateo  county  on  the  west  and  Leaven- 
worth and  Larkin  Streets  on  the  east. 


Police  Department,  July,  1861.* 

Chief  of  Police.— MARTIN  J.  BURKE. 

Commissioners. — President  Board  of  Supervi- 
sors, Police  Judge  and  Chief  of  Police. 

Captains  of  Police.— Win.  Y.  Douglass,  J.  M. 
Welch,  I.  W.  Lees  and  C.  H.  Powers. 

Regular  Policemen.— Stephen  N.  Baker,  B.  S. 
Blitz,  James  S.  Bovee,  A.  D.  Brown,  D.  B.  Brown, 
G.  G.  Bradt.  J.  G.  Chappell,  Alfred  Clark,  James 
II.  Conway,  John  R.  Conway,  Charles  Cook,  John 
L.  Durkee,  H.  H.  Ellis,  L.  Englander,  John  Evatt, 
Jas.  Evrard,  J.  B.  Forner,  Benj.  T.  Hanford,  Jas. 
H.  Hesse,  Richard  Horton,  N.  L.  Jehu,  John 
McCraith,  Charles  McMillan,  J.  B.  Moore,  D.  R. 
Nickerson,  John  C.  Park,  F.  L.  Post,  (property 
clerk)  Benjamin  Pratt  and  Joseph  Wood. 

*  Number  of  Captains  provided  by  law,  four;  salary, 
S1,5C0  per  annum.  Number  of  policemen,  thirty  ;  salary, 
$1,200  per  annum.  The  Act  of  May,  1861,  provides  an  ad- 
ditional force  of  ten— not  yet  appointed.  In  addition  to 
the  regular  force  of  the  department,  there  are  a  number 
of  special  officers  deputized  for  duty  in  particular  sections 
of  the  city,  who  receive  a  compensation  from  the  owners 
of  property  on  their  respective  beats.

bro,  W.  A.  Ashland,  A.  Barbier,  T.  Bertram,

Richard  Colburn,  John  C.  Colter,  R.  T.  Conners.

FIRE    DEPARTMENT.* 

The  Fire  Department  of  San  Francisco  is  com- 
posed of  fourteen  Engine  and  two  Hook  and 
Ladder  Companies,  numbering  eight  hundred  and 
twenty-two  members.  Number  feet  of  Hose, 
8,350.  Number  of  Hydrants,  165.  Expendi- 
tures for  the  Department,  repairs,  etc.  for  the 
years  1860  and  '61,  $30,000. 

Chief  Engineer. — David  Scannell. 

First  Assistant  Engineer. — Sheldon  S.  Gordon. 

Second  Assistant  Engineer. — Edwin  F.  Stewart. 

Third  Assistant  Engineer. — John  G.  Corson. 

Board  of  Delegates. — President,  Franklin 
L.  Jones ;  Secretary,  Michael  Lynch ;  Treasurer, 
M.  Heverin. 

Members. — Broderick  1,  John  Stratman,  Arnop 
Bainbridge;  Manhattan  2,  M.  Heverin,  B.  A. 
Mahon ;  Howard  3,  D.  H.  Rand,  Jas.  Macgovern; 
California  4,  J.  W.  Farren,  C.  Connor ;  Knicker- 

*  For  the  progress  and  present  condition  of  the  Public 
Schools  of  San  Francisco,  see  general  review  at  the  com- 
mencement of  the  work. 

t  George  Tait  is  Superintendent  of  Public  Schools 
from  the  first  Monday  of  October  next. 

X  The' salary  of  the  Chief  Engineer  is  $4,000  per  annum.

$1,200  per  annum.  Secretary  of  the  Board  of  Delegates, 
$1,800  per  annum.

No.  2,  Manhattan  Engine  Company. — House 
situated  on  southerly  side  of  Jackson  Street,  be- 
tween Montgomery  and  Kearii3r,  Company  or- 
ganized January  31th,  1854;  admitted  into  the 
Department  February  4th.  1854.  The  house  is 
two  stories  in  height,  the  first  is  of  granite  and 
the  second  of  brick.  The  lot  is  22  feet  G  inches 
by  68  feet,  and  was  purchased  by  the  city  and 
cost  $7,200,  of  which  amount  the  company  ex- 
pended $700.  The  company  have  now  in  ser- 
vice a  new  second  class  engine,  built  by  Crowing 
&  Co.  Seneca  Falls,  N.  Y.  Size  of  cylinders  s| 
inches.  Stroke  7£  inches.  Cost  $2,000.  Is  the 
property  of  the  city.  Stated  meetings  first  Mon- 
day of  each  month.  The  company  has  forty- 
three  active  members  on  the  roll.  The  first  fore- 
man was  David  L.  Beck,  succeeded  by  Mathew 
Mclntire,  as  acting  foreman,  and  Ira  Cole,  D.  L. 
Beck,  Thomas  J.  Smith,  John  D.  Swift  and  the 
present  foreman.  Officers — Foreman,  Lafayette 
Stivers;  First  Assistant,  Phillip  R.  Leroy;  Se- 
cond Assistant,  Samuel  Appell;  Secretary,  James 
F.  Neville ;  Treasurer,  Henry  Devine. 

No.  3,  Howard  Engine  Company. — House  situ- 
ated on  south  side  of  California  Street,  near  San- 
som.  Company  organized  June  loth,  1850,  found- 
ed by  Samuel  Brannan.  W.  D.  M.  Howard  and 
J.  L.  Folsom,  and  admitted  into  the  Department 
June  16th,  1850.  The  house  now  occupied  by 
the  company  is  a  commodious  three  story  build- 
ing recently  erected  at  a  cost  of,  including  the 
furniture,  S14,400 ;  of  which  the  city  paid  $6,000. 
Size  of  building  23  feet  front  by  sixty  feet  deep. 
Cost  of  lot  $7,000.  purchased  by  the  city.  Hun- 
neman  style  of  engine,  cost  $3,000,  and  is  the 
property  of  the  city.  Size  of  cylinders,  6  inches; 
capacity,  409.91  cubic  inches.  No.  3  has  forty- 
eight  active  members  on  the  roll.  Stated  meet- 
ings first  Wednesday  in  each  month.  The  first 
foreman  was  J.  S.  Eagan,  who  was  succeeded 
respectively  by  F.  E.  R.  Whitney,  Geo.  Melius, 
F.  E.  11.  Whitney,  (second  term)  Jacob  Wells, 
Caleb  Olapp,  W.  II.  Patten,  F.  E.  R.  Whitney, 
(third  term)  W.  T.  Chase,  D.  W.  Crane,  Freder- 
ick L.  Tyler  and  H.  W.  Burkes,  who  was  suc- 
ceeded by  the  present  foreman.  Officers — Fore- 
man, F.  K.  R.  Whitney;  First  Assistant,  Thomas 
McNaughton;  Second  Assistant,  A.  McAbbee; 
Secretary,  J.  O.  B.  Kennedy;  Treasurer,  Chas. 
O.  Turner. 

No.  4,  California  Engine  Co. — House  situated 
on  north  side  Market  near  Battery  street.  Com- 
pany organized  September  7th,  1850;  admitted 
into  the  Department  September  9th,  1850.     The 


house  is  two  stories  in  height,  built  of  brick, 
cemented ;  the  lot  is  62  feet  6  inches  in  depth 
by  27  feet  in  width  ;  purchased  by  the  city  and 
cost  $5,000.  The  house  was  built  by  the  city  at 
a  cost  of  $7,200,  of  which  amount  the  company 
paid  $700.  Style  of  engine,  Hunneman,  cylin- 
ders, 64,  inches:  capacity,  411  cubic  inches; 
cost  $4,200,  and  is  the  property  of  the  company. 
Stated  meetings  held  last  Monday  of  each  month. 
No.  4  lias  forty-seven  active  members  on  the  roll. 
The  first  foreman  was  George  M.  Garwood,  who 
was  succeeded  by  George  N.  Shaw,  Herman  R. 
Haste,  Charles  R.  Bond,  Charles  S.  Simpson, 
Augustus  J.  Ellis,  Isaiah  W.  Lees,  W.  S.  O'Brien 
and  John  W.  Farren,  respectively.  Officers — 
President,  C.  O'Connor;  Foreman,  P. A.  O'Brien, 
First  Assistant,  G.  W.  Hays ;  Second  Assistant, 
A.  H.  Hiutz ;  Secretary,  S.  M.  Johnson ;  Treas- 
urer, C.  H.  Williams. 

No.  5,  Knickerbocker  Engine  Company. — House 
situated  on  the  north  side  Sacramento  near  San- 
som  street.  Company  organized  October  17th, 
1850 ;  admitted  into  the  Department,  October  19, 
1850.  The  house  is  three  stories  in  height,  built 
of  granite;  cost  $13,200.  built  by  the  city.  The 
lot  is  16  feet  by  59  feet  2  inches,  and  was  pur- 
chased by  the  city  for  $5,000.  New  York  style 
of  engine,  constructed  by  James  Smith,  first  class. 
Size  of  cylinders,  10  inches;  stroke  8£  inches; 
cost  $4,000,  of  which  $2,000  was  paid  by  the 
company.  Stated  meetings  held  first  Monday  of 
each  month.  Number  of  active  members,  fifty- 
seven.  The  first  foreman  of  the  company  was 
James  H.  Cutter,  who  was  succeeded  by  Charles 
E.  Buckingham.  The  third  foreman  was  James 
E.  Nuttman,  who  was  followed  by  Edward  S. 
Spear,  who  was  succeeded  by  E.  B.  Vreeland, 
James  E.  Nuttman  (second  term)  William  B. 
Fairman,  Lafayette  Stivers,  E.  Jacob  Chase 
and  the  present  foreman.  The  present  officers 
are — Foreman,  Wm.  N.  Smith  ;  First  Assistant, 
Michael  McCarthy ;  Second  Assistant,  James 
Riley;  Secretary,  James  H.  Reynolds;  Treas- 
urer, Henry  R.  Reed. 

No.  6,  Monumental  Engine  Company. — House 
situated  on  Brenham  Place,  between  Washington 
and  Clay  streets.  Company  organized  September 
10,  1850;  admitted  into  the  Department  Sep- 
tember 12,  1850.  The  house  is  two  stories  in 
height,  the  first  of  granite,  the  second  of  free- 
stone, and  is  of  the  Corinthian  style  of  architec- 
ture. The  lot  is  22  by  65  feet,  purchased  by  the 
city  for  $3,500  ;  the  house,  which  contains  a  fine 
library  of  over  one  thousand  volumes,  was  budt 
by  the  city  and  cost  $10,500,  of  which  amount 
the  company  expended  $4,000.  This  company 
have  two  first  class  engines.  One  a  hand 
steamer,  built  by  Lee  &  Larned,  Novelty  Works, 
New  York  city.  Annular  boiler,  rotary  pumps ; 
weight,  6,300  pounds.  Cost  $5,500.  This  is 
the  pioneer  steam-engine  of  the  State,  it  having 
been  received  by  way  of  Panama,  per  John  L. 
Stephens,  September  2,  1860,  and  placed  in 
active  service  February  2,  1861.  The  other  is  a 
Baltimore  style  hand  engine,  constructed  by  John 
Rodgers ;  cost  $6,000,  paid  for  by  the  company; 
size  of  cylinders,  10  inch  ;  capacity  667.50  cubic

APPENDIX. 


461 


situated  on  north  side  Jackson  between  Kearny 
and  Dupont  Streets.  Company  organized  Sep- 
tember 14th,  1852 ;  admitted  into  the  Department 
November  4jb,  1852.  The  house  is  three  stories 
in  height,  the  first  of  granite,  the  others  of  brick 
cemented;  style  of  architecture,  Corinthian. — 
Cost  $12,500,  built  by  the  city;  of  the  amount 
expended,  the  company  appropriated  $5,500. — 
The  lot  is  2-1  feet  front  byj90  feet ;  purchased  by 
the  city  for  $7,000.  The  company  are  the  own- 
ers of  two  powerful  engines — one  a  hand  engine, 
Philadelphia  style,  constructed  by  Agnew,  cost 
$5,500;  and  the  other  a  steam  apparatus  built  by 
Neafie  ft  Levy,  Philadelphia.  The  latter  was  re- 
ceived by  the  company  on  the  17  th  day  of  Janu- 
ary, 1861,  under  contract  authorized  by  a  resolu- 
tion passed  March  7,  1860.  Cylinder  8  inch  bore, 
12  inch  stroke ;  pump  4£  inch  bore,  12  inch  stroke. 
Also  a  hose-carriage  capable  of  carrying  1000 
feet  of  hose.  Cost  of  engine  $4,339  25;  car- 
riage $761  30;  of  which  amount  the  company 
contributed  the  sum  of  $2,800,  the  balance  hav- 
ing been  subscribed  by  the  citizens  of  the  city. 
Stated  meetings  first  "Wednesday  of  each  month. 
Number  of  active  members  sixty-three.  The 
first  foreman  of  the  company  was  H.  S.  Brown, 
the  second  Robert  B.  Quayle,  who  was  succeed- 
ed by  Edward  T.  Batturs,  John  Hanna,  Robert 
Pollock,  Frank  G.  Edwards,  and  the  present  in- 
cumbent. Officers. — President,  Franklin  L.  Jones; 
Foreman.  John  Hanna;  First  Assistant,  George 
Overn:  Secretary,  James  S.  Thompson;  Treas- 
urer, Thomas  Tennent. 

No.  13,  Young  America  Engine  Company. — 
House  situated  on  Sixteenth  between  Guerrero 
and  Valencia  streets,  Mission  Dolores.  Company 
organized  February  7,  1854 ;  admitted  into  the  De- 
partment April  12th,  1854.  The  house  and  en- 
closure were  built  by  the  city  at  a  cost  of  $8,300, 
of  which  amount  the  company  appropriate 
It  is  two  stories  in  height,  built  of  granite,  in  the 
Elizabethian  style  of  architecture.  The  lot,  22 
by  85  feet,  cost  "$600,  bought  by  the  city. 
of  engine,  New  York,  constructed  by  James 
Smith,  cost  $2,000,  purchased  by  the  city;  size  of 
cylinders  6  inches.  The  company  has  sixty- four 
active  members  on  the  roll.  Stated  meetings 
first  Friday  of  each  month.  The  first  foreman 
was  James  G.  Deniston,  who  was  succeded  by 
S.  Courtier,  in  whose  place  M.  Hayes  was  elect- 
ed who  was  succeeded  by  the  present  foreman. 
Officers. — Foreman,  Wm.  Shear:  First  Assistant, 
P.  If c  An  tee;  Secretary,  M.  Lynch;  Treasurer, 
Isaac  V.  Denniston. 

No.  14,  Tiger  Engine  Company. — House  situ- 
ated on  westerly  side  of  Second  between  How- 
ard and  Natoma  streets.  Company  organized 
February  2 2d,  1855;  admitted  into  the  Depart- 
ment December  17,  1855.  The  house  is  a  brick 
building,  and  cost,  to  complete,  $7,500.  Size  of 
lot  25  feet  wide  by  80  feet  in  depth.  This  com- 
pany has  a  powerful  Hunneman  engine,  purchas- 
ed at  an  expense  of  $3,500;  size  of  cylinders  6 
5-7  inches,  owned  by  the  company.  The  com- 
pany has  forty-eight  members  upon  the  roll. — 
Stated  meetings  first  Monday  of  each  month. — 


The   first   foreman   of  the   company  was  Calebi  mental  Engine  House, 


Clapp,  who  was  succeeded  by  P.  C.  "Wilkinson, 
John  Carroll  and  the  present  foreman.  Officers. 
— Foreman,  P.  C.  Wilkinson;  First  Assistant, 
Wm.  Boyd;  Second  Assistant,  Win.  II.  1'arcells: 
Recording  Secretary,  Charles  Taylor:  Financial 
Secretary,  S.  Barker;  Treasurer,  Win.  Boltz. 

No.  1,  St.  Francis  Hook  and  Ladder  Company. — 
House  situated  on  Dupont,  westerly  side,  between 
Clay  and  Sacramento  streets.  Company  organ- 
ized June  15,  1850;  admitted  into  the  Depart- 
ment June  17,  1850.  The  house  is  two  stories 
in  height,  built  of  brick,  cemented.  Style  of 
architecture,  a  combination  of  Ionic  and  Corin- 
thian. Cost  of  building.  $7,000,  of  which  amount 
the  company  appropriated  $500 ;  it  is  owned  by 
the  city.  The  lot  is  23  by  60  feet,  purchased  by 
the  city  for  $5,000.  Truck  constructed  in  San 
Francisco,  cost  $4,500,  paid  for  by  the  city.  The 
company  has  fifty  active  members  on  the  roll. 
Stated  meetings  first  Monday  of  each  month. 
The  first  foreman  was  Joseph  C.  Palmer,  who 
was  succeeded  respectively  by  J.  P.  Buckley, 
G.  W.  Gibbs,  L.  H.  Robie,  George  A.  Worn, 
Jacob  Ezekiel,  and  the  present  foreman. 
Officers  —  President,  Daniel  Davis  ;  Foreman, 
Charles  Schultz ;  First  Assistant,  M.  Fenster- 
macher;  Second  Assistant.  M.Harris;  Secreta- 
ry, W.  A.  Chase :  Treasurer,  J.  I.  H.  Knowles. 

No.  2,  Lafayette  Eook  and  Ladder  Company. — 
House  situated  on  southerly  side  of  Bioadway 
between  Stockton  and  Dupont  streets.  Company 
organized  June  1,  1853;  admitted  into  the  De- 
partment, September  19th,  1853.  The  house  is 
two  stories  in  height,  built  of  brick,  cemented. 
Italian  style  of  architecture;  cost  $7,100,  of 
which  amount  tfho  company  appropriated  $600; 
owned  by  the  city.  Lot  22  feet  5  inches  by  130 
feet,  bought  by  the  city  for  $4,000.  The  truck 
was  constructed  in  San  Francisco;  cost  $4,500, 
paid  for  by  the  city.  The  company  has  fifty- 
eight  active  members  on  the  roll.  Stated  meet- 
ings held  first  Tuesday  of  each  month.  The 
first  foreman  was  H.  A.  Cobb,  who  was  suc- 
ceeded by  D.  Bovrat,  and  the  present  foreman. 
Officers — President,  De  Pigne  Dupuytren ;  Fore- 
man, L.  Prudon ;  First  Assistant,  0.  P.  Arees; 
Second  assistant,  P.  Huant;  Secretary  F.  Gar- 
nier ;  Treasurer,  J.  Hertcman. 

Exempt  Fire  Company. — Organized  in  accord- 
ance with  Section  15  of  an  Act  of  the  Legisla- 
ture "To  regulate  the  Fire  Department  of  the 
city  of  San  Francisco,"  approved  March  25th, 
1857,  which  reads  as  follows:  " Exempt  mem- 
bers of  the  Department  may  organize  themselves 
to  be  known  and  designated  as  the  Exempt  Fire 
Company,  etc.,  and  shall  be  entitled  to  equal  re- 
lief from  the  Fire  Department  Charitable  Fund; 
but  they  shall  have  no  vote,  or  other  representa- 
tion in  the  Department."  Officers — President, 
G.  II.  Hossefross;  Vice  Presidents.  J.  L.  Van 
Bokkelen,  and  G.  W.  Gibbs;  Treasurer,  Clement 
on;  Secretary,  G.  A.  nobe.  Annual 
election  of  officers,  second  Monday  in  October. 
Quarterly  Meetings,  second  Monday  of  January, 
April,  July  and  October.  Admission  fee,  $2; 
quarterly  dues,  $1.     Meetings  held  at  the  Monu 


462 


SAN    FRANCISCO    DIRECTORY 


Independence  Fire  Company. — This  is  the  name 
of  an  independent  company  formed  in  1859  by 
the  citizens  of  St.  Ann's  Valley.  They  have  in 
use  a  small  New  York  side-stroke  engine.  The 
house  of  the  company  is  located  corner  Powell 
and  Eddy  streets.  Officers— President,  David 
Dwyer;  Foreman,  0.  B.  Oakley;  First 
ant,  Silas  M.  Locke;  Second  Assistant.  James 
Peach ;  Secretary.  A.  J.  Moon ;  Treasurer.  X.  C. 
Lane. 

Washington  Hose  Company  {Independent). — 
House  situated  N  side  Green  above  Stockton. 
Organized  August  10,   1860.     Expenses  of  or- 


ganization contributed  bv  the  citizens  of  the 
Second  District.  Number  of  members,  twenty 
five.  Stated  meetings  first  Wednesday  of  each 
month.  Officers— Foreman.  Thomas  Finnerty 
First  Assistant.  Jeremiah  Smith;  Secretarv  A 
J.  Randall ;  Treasurer.  J.  H.  Mullen. 

ty  Boae  Company  {Independent).— House 
located  205  Fourth.  Number  of  active  members 
twenty-five.  Stated  meetings  first  Thursday  of 
each  month.  Officers— President,  W.  C.  Fad 
Foreman,  Thomas  Sawyer;  Secretarv,  Henri 
Bockman;  Recording  Secretarv,  Win.  F.  Tracy 
Treasurer,  Herman  Ranken.

U.  S.  Branch  Mint, 

North  ride  of  Commercial  n»  nery. 

The  law  for  the  establishment  and  regulation 
of  the   Qnil  Mint  and  the  branches 

thereof,  provides  tbal  any  person  may  deposit 

with  lli  'Id  and 

silver  in  bullion,  grain  or  lumps,  which,  If  re- 
bars  01  ok  alter  the 

BOf,  the  bar- 
mint  or  branches,  In  such  mat  sll  indi- 
cate the  fineness  and  value  ol  the  ex* 
•  lined  from 


so  made,  at  such  rates  and  charges  and  under 
such  regulations,  as  may  from  time  to  time  be 
established.  The  said  charges  not  to  exceed  the 
actual  cost  of  refining,  casting  and  forming  said 
bars,  including  labor,  wastage,  use  of  machinery, 
material,  etc.  or  $  per  cent,  for  coinage,  to  be  re- 
ceived by  the  Treasurer  of  the  Mint  at  which  the 
deposit  was  made,  and  by  him  accounted  for  to 
the  Treasurer  of  the  United  States. 

Office  hours  from  9  o'clock  A.  M.  to  2  P.  M. 
Gold  Bullion  received  daily  from  9  o'clock  A 
M.  to  12  M. :  Silver  Bullion  from  12  M.  to  1 
P.  M.  Yisitors  admitted,  daily,  from  9  o'clock 
A.  M.  to  12  o'clock  M.

APPEND  IX. 


465 


Mails  for  San  Jose,  etc.,  closed  daily  at 
7:45    A.  M. 

Mails  for  Santa  Barbara.  Los  Angeles  and  San 
are  dispatched  Mondays,  Wednesdays  and 
Fridays,  aud  on  the  1st,  11th,  and  2lst  of  each 
month. 

Mails  for  Acapulco,  Panama,  and  South 
America,  are  forwarded  on  each   month. 

Mails  for  China,  the  Sandwich  Islands,  and 
Australia,  are  forwarded  from  the  Post  Office  by 


every  suitable  opportunity,  containing  all  letters 
and  papers,  the  inland  postage  of  which  is  pre- 
paid to  San  Francisco,  leaving  the  sea  postage 
to  be  collected  in  the  ports  where  the  mails  arc 
delivered. 

Letters  cannot  be  sent  unless  fully  pre-paid 
by  stamps.  Drop  Letters  must  be  pre-paid  by 
postage  stamps,  or  they  will  not  be  delivered. 
Letters  will  not  be  sent  with  stamps  cut  from 
stamped  envelops. 


COURTS, 


HELD  IX  SAX  FRAXCISCO. 


United  States  District  Court. — Northern  Dis- 
trict.— Regular  terms  held  in  San  Francisco  first 
Monday  of  June  and  December.  Special  terms 
at  the  discretion  of  the  Court.  Judge,  Hon. 
Ogden  Hoffman;  Attorney,  W.  H.  Sharp:  Mar- 
shal, Wm.  Rabe ;  Deputies,  James  F.  Curtis, 
David  R.  McKee,  James  H.  Rogers,  and  Henry 
Johnson;  Clerk,  W.  H.  Chevers. 

United  States  Circuit  Court — District  of  Cali- 
— Regular  term  held  in  San  Francisco  first 
Monday  of  January  and  July.  Special  terms  at 
the  discretion  of  the  Court.  Judge,  Hon.  M  Hall 
McAllister:  Associate,  non.  Ogden  Hoffman; 
Attorney,  W.  H.  Sharp;  Clerk,  Cutler  McAllister; 
Marshal,  Wm.  Rabe  ;  Deputies  (as  above.) 

Supreme  Court  of  California. — Regular  terms 
held  at  Sacramento  first  Mouday  in  January, 
April,  July  and  October.  Chief  Justice,  Hon. 
Stephen  J.  Field;  Associates,  J.  G.  Baldwin 
and  W.  W.  Cope;  Clerk,  Charles  S.  Fairfax; 
Reporter,  David  T.  Bagley. 

District  Court — Fourth  District — Regular  terms 
first  Monday  of  February,  April,  June,  August, 
October  and  December.  Judge,  Hon.  John  S. 
Hager;  Clerk,  Washington  Bartlett;  Deputy, 
Charles  S.  Capp;  Sherilf,  Charles  Doane  ;  Bailiff, 
D.  W.  C.  Thompson. 

District  Court — Twelfth  District. — Regular 
terms  first  Monday  of  January,  March,  May, 
July.  September  and  November.  Judge,  Hon. 
Alexander  Campbell;  Clerk,  Washington  Bart- 
lett;  Deputy,  S.  L.  Lupton;  Sheriff,  Charles 
Doane ;  Bailiff,  John  A.  Clark. 

County  Court. — Regular  terms  first  Monday  of 
January,  and  of  each  alternate  month  thereafter. 
Judge,  Hon.  M.  C.  Blake;  Clerk,  Washington 
Bartlett:  Deputy,  Wm.  Harney;  Sheriff,  Charles 
Doane  ;  Bailiff,  Wm.  H.  Silverthorn. 

Court  of  Sessions. — Regular  terms  first  Monday 
of  February,  and  of  each  alternate  mouth  there- 


34 


after.  Hon.  M.  C.  Blake,  presiding  Judge ;  Hous. 
George  Robins  and  Townsend  Bagley,  Associates; 
Clerk,  Washington  Bartlett;  Deputy,  Wm.  Har- 
ney: Bailiff,  Wm.  H.  Silverthorn. 

Probate  Court. — Regular  terms  third  Monday 
of  January,  and  of  each  alternate  month  there- 
after. Judge,  Hon.  M.  C.  Blake:  Clerk,  Wash- 
ington Bartlett;  Deputy,  Columbus  Bartlett; 
Sheriff.  Charles  Doane ;  Bailiff,  William  H. 
Silverthorn. 

Police  Court. — Sessions  held  daily.  Judge, 
Samuel  Cowles  ;  Pros.  Att'y,  P.  W.  Shepheard . 
Clerk,  John  H.  Titcomb;  Interpreters,  J.  Lussey 
and  C.  Cavalho ;  Bailiff,  Capt.  James  M.  Welch. 


JUSTICES'  COURTS. 

(sessions  daily.) 

First  Township — First  and  Second  Wards. — 
Justice,  R.  J.  Tobin ;  Constable,  P.  Crowley; 
office,  53G  Pacific  near  Kearny. 

Second  Township —  Third  and  Fourth  Districts. 
— Justice,  Wm.  H.  Culver;  Constables,  Samuel 
C.  Harding;  office,  623  Merchant. 

Third  Township — Fifth  and  Sixth  Districts. — 
Justice,  Benjamin  H.  Carman ;  Constable,  Mig- 
hill  Smith  ;  office,  528  Montgomery. 

Fourth  Township — Seventh  and  Eighth  Dis- 
tricts. —  Justice,  George  Robins ;  Constable, 
Joshua  Hilton ;  office,  230  Bush  nr  Montgomery. 

Fifth  Township — Ninth  and  Tenth  Districts. — 
Justice,  C.  S.  Whitney;  Constable,  J.  C.  Appell; 
office,  613  Market  near  Second. 

Sixth  Township — Eleventh  and  Twelfth  Dis- 
tricts.— Justice,  Martin  W.  Lamb ;  Constable, 
George  W.  Glidden;  office,  SE  cor  Mission  and 
Fifteenth.

present  church  property,  including  lot,  building 
ami  repairs,  has  been  about  $70,<

EPISCOPAL. 
Grace  Church. 

Eectorship  vacant.  Location,  W  side  Powell 
:i  Jackson  and  Pacific. 

Public  services  every  Sunday  at  11  A.  M.  and 
7^  P.  M. ;  Sunday  School  at  half-past  one  in  the 
afternoon.  This  convenient  structure  was  erected 
in  1851,  and  is  one  of  the  oldest  in  the  city.  The 
congregation  was  organized  in  1849,  the  statis- 
tics of  which  may  be  summed  up  as  follows: 
Communicants.  '200;  the  Sunday  School  numbers 
about  200  scholars,  and  has  a  library  of  over  300 
volumes.  The  first  rector  of  the  church  was 
Dr.  J.  L.  Ver  Mehr,  who  preached  his  first 
sermon  in  California  at  the  house  of  Mr.  Merrill. 
in  this  city.  September  10th,  1849.  The  church 
was  then  in  embryo,  not  yet  having  been  duly 
organized.  A  party  of  gentlemen  soon  after 
invited  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  to  preach  at  Frank  Ward's 
house,  situated  on  the  corner  of  Stockton  and 
Green  streets.  A  chapel  was  next  built  towards 
the  close  of  1S49,  at  the  corner  of  John  and 
Powell  streets,  which  was  first  opened  lor  divine 
services,  December  30th,  1849.  This  was  the 
first  Grace  Church.  It  was  GO  feet  long  by  20 
feet  wide,  and  cost  §8,000.  The  bell'is  that 
used  in  the  present  Grace  Church,  on  Powell 
street.  It  weighs  800  pounds,  cost  $350,  and 
has  called  the  faithful  to  prayers  from  the  first 
It  was  presented  by  Mr.  Frank  Ward.  On  the 
28th  of  April,  1850,  Grace  Church  was  formally 
organized,  and  came  into  being.  E.  Bryant  and 
D  S.  Turner  were  elected  Wardens,  and  Dr.  Ver 
Mehr  chosen  Rector.  The  first  vestry  meeting 
was  held  on  May  20th,  1850 — eleven  years  ago. 
In  February,  1851,  the  contract  was  made  to 
build  the  present  Grace  Church  on  Powell  street, 
which  was  finished  that  summer.  Its  dimen- 
sions are  68£  feet  in  length,  and  38  feet  4  inches 
in  width.  The  entire  length,  counting  the 
chancel,  is  97  feet  4  inches.  The  tower  is  60 
feet  in  height.  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  preached  the  first 
sermon  in  this  edifice.  Bishop  Kip  arrived  in 
San  Francisco  January  29th,  1854,  and  on  the 
25th  of  February  following,  assumed  the  Rector- 
ship, at  which  time  Dr.  Ver  Mehr  resigned.  The 
Bishop  continued  to  officiate  until  Palm  Sunday, 
April  5th,  1857, 'when  F.  C.  Ewer  was  ordained, 
and  on  the  next  Sunday  he  preached  his  first 
sermon.  On  the  14th  of  April  Mr.  Ewer  was 
elected  to  be  Assistant  Minister,  and  on  the  20th 
of  the  same  month  he  took  charge  of  the  parish, 
the  Bishop  having  departed  for  the  Atlantic 
States.  The  Bishop  having  returned  and  re- 
signed the  Rectorship,  Mr.  Kwer  was  elected 
Rector  of  the  Church  on  the  15th  of  December, 


1857,  and  retained  that  position  till  April,  1861, 
when  he  resij 

The  congregation  are  now  erecting  at  the  SE 
corner  Stockton  and  California  streets, a  commo- 
dious and  substantial  church  edifice,  which  will 
be.  when  completed,  one  of  the  finest  church 
buildings  on  the  coast.  The  church  will  cover 
an  area  of  137A  feet  by  68  feet,  and  will  contain 
within  its  walls  every  convenience  n& 
to  carry  out  the  holy  objects  for  which  it  was 
erected. 

OJicers.— "Wardens,  J.  W.  Wilde,  Sr.,  Hon. 
Edward  Stanly;  Vestrymen,  R.  .1.  Yandewater, 
E.  Pringle,  Stephen  Smith,  D.  S.  Turner,  (',.  W. 
Gibbs,  II.  F.  Williams.  H.  C.  Parker,  C.  O.  Ger- 
berdiug,  and  William  Blanding. 

Trinity  Church. 

Rev.  S.  C.  Thrall,  Rector;  Church  located 
X  side  of  Pine  between  Montgomery  and  Kearny. 
Pastor's  residence  24  Minna:  organized,  1S50. 

Public  Worship  every  Sunday  11  A.  M.  and 
7i  P.  M. ;  daily,  11  A.  M.  and  Wednesday  and 
Friday  4  P.  M.;  Sunday  School.  9i  A.  M. 

Officers.— Wardens,  J.  D.  Hawks.  Sr.,  B.  II. 
Randolph,  Jr. ;  Vestrymen,  S.  R.  Throckmorton, 
II.  P.  Janes.  W.  F.  Babcock.  James  Bell.  Jacob 
Underbill;  W.  L.  Booker,  J.  C.  McCeney.  Clerk, 
Jos.  G.  Eastland. 

St.  John's  Church,  Mission  Dolores. 

Rectorship  vacant. 

This  Church  was  established  in  November, 
1857 — the  Rev.  John  Chittenden,  President  of 
the  San  Francisco  College,  then  a  lay  reader, 
licensed  by  the  Bishop  of  the  Diocese,  officia- 
ting as  its  minister.  -The  parish,  of  which  this 
is  the  church,  was  instituted  in  February,  1858, 
and  it  is  now  in  a  state  of  forwardness,  to  be 
permanently  received  as  such  into  the  Diocese 
of  California.  It  is  of  the  Protestant  Episcopal 
Church,  and  has  all  the  privileges  of  other 
churches  in  the  Episcopate.  It  is  a  neat  edifice, 
and  is  thoroughly  furnished  with  organ,  robing- 
room,  altar,  pulpit  and  vestment.  The  inhabi- 
tants are  indebted  mainly  to  the  liberality  of  a 
few  individuals  and  to  the  Rev.  John  Chittenden 
for  the  first  introduction  of  this  church  service 
into  the  neighborhood.  The  Rev.  J.  Cameron, 
ordained  in  April  last,  officiated  as  Curate — the 
Rev.  J.  Chittenden  being  his  Rector.  By  the 
energy  of  the  Curate,  assisted  by  his  brother 
clergymen,  he  has  established  the  Episcopal 
Church  permanently  in  this  vicinity.  Services 
are  held  at  different  hours,  from  11  A.  M.  to  3 
P.  M.,  to  suit  the  attendants.  It  is  worthy  of 
being  noted,  that  the  Ministers,  Organist  (Mr. 
Theodoro  Smith),  Choir,  and  other  assistants, 
give  their  services  gratuitously.  The  church 
can  accommodate  upwards  of  200  persons. 

Church  of  the  Advent. 

Rev.  F.  Marion  McAllister,  Rector;  Resi- 
dence 928  Clay. 

The  Parish  was  established,  with  its  first  and 
present  Rector,  June,  1858. 

This  church  is  located  on  Howard  Street  be-

SAN      FRANCISCO      DIRECTORY. 


tween  Second  and  Third  Streets.     It  was  com- 
pleted and  consecrated  February  24th,   1861. 

Services  every  Sunday  at  11  A.  M.  and  7£  P. 
M.:  Sunday  School  at  9  A.  M. 

Officers. — Wardens,  H.  S.  Austin  sr.  and  Cut- 
ler McAllister;  Vestrymen,  L.  A.  Garnett, 
Eastman,   J.   J.    Williams,   J.  Van  Dyke,  T.  R. 
Johnson,  Hall  McAllister  and  C.  Langli 

The  new  church,  with  its  lofty  steeple, 
forms  a  conspicuous  object  in  the  southern  pari 
of  the  city.  The  architecture  is  nearly  pure 
Gothic.  Some  modifications  in  the  Romanesque 
Btylehave  been  introduced,  adding  materially  to 
the  light  and  graceful  effect  The  exterior  is  of 
a   rich  dark  brown,  and,  with  its  lofty  lantern. 

•.  Dunstan's  in  the  Bast 
don,   built  by  Sir  Christopher  Wren,  and  copied 
by  him  from  the  tine  old  church  of  St.  Nicholas, 
New  i  and 

The  interior  is  plain  and  elegant,  and  offering 
an  auditorium  in  the  clear  of  fifty  feet  by  eighty, 
or  one  hundred  and  twenty  feet  in  depth  with 
incel  The  walls  are  painted  in  imitation 
■.  the  ceiling,  which  is  divided  with  deli- 
cate tracery.  Bpringa  gradually  to  the  apex  of  the 
roof,  ami  is  painted  light  blue.  The  chancel  is  n 
model  of  neat,  unpretending  architecture,  and 
with  the  pulpit,  which  is  very  high,  Is  much  in 
the  old]  yle.    A  very  attractive  feature 

is  the  Ten  Commandments,  which  (ill   up  the 

Bt  the  rear  of  the  cliancel.     The  windows 

ty  and  divided  into  diamond-shap 

i  the  inside. 
The  lot.  with  the  edifice  and  furniture,  cost  the 
society  twenty-seven  thousand  dollars.

Folsom  Street  Methodist  Episcopal  Church. 

Rev.  S.  D.  Simoxds.  Pastor;  Residence,  rear 
of  Church.  Location,  Folsom  Street  !• 
First  and  Second.  Sunday  morning  and  evening 
service  at  the  usual  hours:  seats  free.  Sunday 
School  at  2  P.  M.  Prayer  Meeting  etc.  on  Wed- 
nesday evening. 

This  Society,  organized  in  1852,  under  the  su- 
perintendence of  Rev.  Isaac  Owen,  erected,  and 
dedicated  December  5th,  1853,  a  plain,  but  sub- 
stantial, neatly  furnished  house  of  worship.  The 
Society  has  a  valuable  property  and  is  out  of 
debt.  The  number  of  communicants  was,  in 
September,  1858,  7ii;  since  which  50  bai 
added:  making  in  all.  120,  up  to  February  of  the 
year.  A  deep  religious  interest  pervades 
the  Society.  Sabbath  School  Superintendent, 
Wm.  H.  Coddington;  number  of  teachen 
scholars,  270;  new  volumes  in  the  librar 

Bethel  Methodist  Episcopal  Church.

This  Church  was  organized  early  in  1851,  un- 
der the   pastoral  charge  of  Rev.  W.  Taylor. — 

Service   was   then  held  in  the  ship    Panama,    on 

Davis  Street.    Subsequently  the  ship  was  moved 
to  the  foot  of  Mission  Street,  and  a  church  built 

on  deck.      Baity    in    1851    the  church  was  taken 
down  and  rebuilt  in  its  present  eligible  situation

derson  has  been  the  Pastor  of  this  Church. 
Public  services  every  Sabbath  at  the  usual

Methodist  Episcopal  Church,  Zion  (colored.) 

Rev.  Joiix  J.  Moore,  Pastor.  Residence  N  s 
Pacific  near  Hyde ;  Location,  Pacific  nr  Powell. 

This  congregation  was  organized  by  Rev.  John 
J.  Moore,  the  late  pastor,  August  1st,  1852.  Up 
to  August  13,  1856,  worship  was  held  in  a  frame 
building  on  Stockton  street,  opposite  the  Marine 
Hospital,  since  which  service  has  been  held  in 
the  present  brick  edifice,  one  story  of  which  is 
finished.  It  was  dedicated  September  7th,  1856. 
The  expenditure  on  this  building,  thus  far,  has 
been  £±,000.  Attached  to  the  congregation  is 
an  interesting  Sabbath  School,  numbering  about 
35  pupils,  6  teachers,  and  a  Library  of  500  vol- 
umes ;  Madison  Bell,  Sup.  Public  services  and 
Sabbath  School  every  Suuday  at  the  usual  hours. 


PRESBYTERIAN. 

First  Presbytearian  Church. 

Rev.  W.  C.  Anderson,  D.  D.  Pastor.  Resi- 
dence, E  s  Powell  between  Clay  and  Washing- 
ton ;  Location,  Stockton  Street  near  Clay.  Ser- 
vices on  Sabbath  at  11  o'clock  A.  M.,  and  7j  P. 
M.  Sabbath  School  and  Bible  Class  at  1  o'clock 
P.  M.  Lecture  on  Wednesday  evening  at  7  5 
o'clock. 

This  church  was  organized  May  20th,  1849, 
under  the  direction  of  the  Rev.  Albert  Williams, 
and  was  the  first  Protestant  Church  organized 
in  San  Francisco.  W.  W.  Caldwell,  Frederick 
Billings,  Dr.  Ceo.  F.  Turner,  Mrs.  Sarah  B.  Gil- 
lespie, Mrs.  Ann  Hodgson,  and  Mrs.  Margaret 
A.  Geary,  were  the  original  members;  Capt.  B. 
Simmons,  E.  Woodrull"  aud  11.  Grimes,  were  the 
firbt  trustees. 

During  the  summer  of  1849,  the  congregation 
worshipped  in  a  tent  on  Dupont  Street,  after- 
ward in  a  storeroom  of  the  Custom  House,  and 
in  the  Superior  Court  room,  City  Hall,  until  Jan- 
uary, 19th,  1851,  when  a  neat  Gothic  edifice, 
capable  of  holding  seven  hundred  persons,  was 
dedicated.  This  house  was  destroyed  by  the 
great  fire  of  22d  June,  1851.  A  plain  building 
Was  immediately  erected,  in  which  the  congre- 
gation worshiped  until  August,  1857  ;  and  from 
that  time  till  May,  1858,  their  meetings  were 
held  in  the  Chinese  Mission  Chapel.  Their  pre- 
sent fine  house  of  worship  was  built  in  the  sum- 
mer and  autumn  of  1857.  at  a  cost  of  about  fif- 
ty thousand  dollars,  including  the  lot,  furniture 
and  fixtures.  It  is  in  the  Gothic  style  of  archi- 
tecture throughout.  The  main  building  is  117 
feet  long,  or  to  the  outside  of  the  tower,  12.'!j: 
and  is  61  feet  wide.  Rooms  for  the  Pastor's 
study  and  social  meetings,  are  on  the  same  floor 
with  the  audience  room,  which  last  is  81  by  58 
feet;  with  a  ceiling  39  feet  high.  A  Sabbath 
]  School  room  57  by  36,  is  over  the  front  apart- 
ments; on  the  north-east  corner  of  the  house, 
there  is  a  brick  tower  96  feet  in  height.  There  is 


an  organ  gallery  that  will  seat  a  choir  of  forty 
persons.  In  all  its  arrangements  the  edifice  is 
admirably  adapted  to  its  purpose,  and  at  the 
same  time,  is  in  accordance  with  true  architec- 
tural taste. 

Office) s. — Rev.  W.  C.  Anderson,  D.  D.  Pas- 
tor; R.  II.  Waller,  N.  Gray,  S.  Hopkins  and  W. 
W.  Caldwell,  Elders;  John  D.  Arthur,  L.  B.  Ed- 
wards,  Samuel  Irving,.  Henry  L.  King,  Chileon 
Beach,  James  K.  S.  Latham,  William  Elder, 
James  Bowman  and  Richard  J.  Nichols,  Trus- 
tees. 

The  Church  is  in  a  very  prosperous  condition, 
more  than  80  members  having  been  added  to  its 
communion,  and  the  number  of  its  pew-holders 
more  than  doubled  in  the  past  year.  Present 
number  of  communicants  280.  Sabbath  School 
Superintendent,  S.  B.  Stoddard;  number  of  teach- 
ers 30;  whole  number  of  scholars  280;  average 
attendance  of  scholars  for  April,  247 ;  a  tine  li- 
brary of  over  2,000  volumes  is  attached  to  the 
school. 

Calvary  Presbyterian  Church. 

Rev.  W.  A.  Scott,  D.  D.,  Pastor;  Location 
north  side  of  Bush  Street,  between  Montgomery 
and  Sansom.  Services  every  Sabbath,  at  11  A. 
M.  and  at  7  P.  M.,  in  winter  months,  and  at  7-J- 
P.  M.  in  summer.  Public  lecture  Wednesday 
evening ;  Prayer  Meeting  Sabbath  evening,  one 
hour  before  the  evening  service.  Sabbath  School 
every  Sabbath  at  9£  A.  M.,  Jas.  B.  Roberts,  Su- 
perintendent. 

Officers. — Elders,  R.  McKee,  Henry  P.  Coon, 
James  D.  Thornton,  Jas.  B.  Roberts ;  Deacons, 
Edward  Hagthrop.  Z.  Snyder;  Trustees,  F.  Hen- 
derson, John  Middleton,  Jas.  B.  Roberts,  H.  II. 
Haight,  A.  P.  Stanford,  R.'  B.  Woodward,  Frank 
Baker,  H.  II.  Bancroft  and  II.  M.  Newhall. 

This  church  was  erected  in  the  fall  of  1854,  at 
a  cost,  including  the  lot,  of  about  $70,000.  On 
its  completion,  the  property  was  largely  in  debt, 
but  the  debt  was  gradually  reduced,  and  finally 
wholly  extinguished.  The  whole  property  is 
now  entirely  free  from  debt,  and  the  income  of 
the  church,  now  some  $13,000,  from  pew  rents 
and  Sabbath  collections,  is  ample  to  meet  all  its 
current  expenses.  The  church  has  a  splendid 
organ,  built  by  Henry  Erben,  of  New  York, 
which  cost  over  $8,000.  This  is,  iuall  respects, 
the  largest  and  most  costly  organ  on  the  Pacific 
coast,  and  it  has  few  superiors  eveu  in  the  At- 
lantic States.  It  has  46  stops,  and  over  2,000 
pipes.  The  greatest  variety  of  combinations  can 
be  made  by  the  use  of  the  various  stops  and 
couplings;  and  for  excellence  of  workmanship, 
and  sweetness  of  tone,  it  has  been  pronounced 
by  judges  to  be  unsurpassed.  Mr.  G.  A.  Scott 
presides  as  organist. 

The  church  building  will  seat  comfortably  1000 
persons.  The  number  of  communicants  is  now 
about  360.  The  number  of  scholars  and  teach- 
ers in  the  Sabbath  School  is  about  225;  number 
of  volumes  in  the  library,  1000,  which  were  se- 
lected with  great  care,  aud  form  a  very  complete 
library.  Connected  with  the  church  is  a  deposi- 
tory of  the  books  of  the  Presbyterian  Board  of 
Publication,  in  which  there  is  kept  a  variety  of  the 


470 


SAX      FRANCISCO      DIRECTORY, 


standard   books   and  tracts   published  by  that 
Board.

titer  Junipero  Serra,  the  founder  of  the  California 
Missions.  The  first  Friar  who  had  charge  was 
Francisco  Patau,  who  was  assisted  in  his  labors 
by  Benito  Cambon.     At  the  organization  of  this 

Mission,  and  for  its  protection,  there  were  15 
soldiers  located  at  the  Presidio,  under  the  com- 
mand of  S.  Flores.  A  cemetery  is  attached  to 
the  Church,  in  which  the  first'  interment  was 
made  in  September,  1770.  The  first  Indian 
convert  was  baptized  on  the  27th  December  of 
the  same  year.  In  the  introductory  portion  of 
the  present  volume,  page  5.  will  be  found  further 
details  connected  with  the  history  of  this  Mission. 
Attached  to  this  Church  is  the  College  of  St. 
Thomas.

SWEDENBORGIAX. 
New  Jerusalem  Church. 

Public  service  held  every  Sabbath  morning  at 
11  o'clock  A.  M..  in  the  rooms  of  the  Twelfth 
District  Court.  City  Hall.  Administration  of  the 
Sacrament  of  the  Lord's  Supper,  at  the  residence 
of  Jas.  Kellogg,  on  Silver  street,  between  Third 
and  Fourth  streets,  on  the  first  Sundays  of  Janu- 
ary, April.  Julv  and  October,  at  2i  o'clock  P.  M. 

Officers— President.  Thos.  S.  Miller;  Treas- 
urer. John  McCraith;  Secretary,  L.  L.  Blood; 
Chorister.  Benj.  Shellard;  Readers,  J.  II.  Purkitt 
and  James  Kellogg;  Librarian  and  Superintend- 
ent of  Sabbath  School,  Dr.  A.  A.  Keltaf 

A  Library,  containing  all  the  Scientific  and 
Theological  works  of  Swedenborg,  and  a  large 
collection  of  the  collateral  works  of  the  Xew 
Church,  both  English  and  American,  is  kept  at 
Dr.  Kellogg's  Drug  Store,  on  Jackson  street 
above  Montgomery. 

The  Church  was  organized  in  1851. 


UNITARIAN. 

First  Unitarian  Church. 
Rev.  THOMAS  Starr  King,  Pastor.  Location, 
Vest  Bide  of  Stockton  street,  betweeu  Clay  and 
Sacramento.  Services  Sunday  at  11  A.  M.  and 
Ih  P.  M.  Sabbath  School  Sunday  at  1  P.  M. 
Pastor's  residence,  Xo.  831  Bush  street.  Fast  of 
Taylor.  This  society  was  organized  September 
1,  1850.  The  present  edifice  owned  by  the 
society  was  erected  in  1852,  and  dedicated  July 
17th,  1853.  The  first  regular  Pastor,  the  Rev. 
Joseph  Harrington,  arrived  August  27th,  1852, 
and  died  November  2d  of  same  year,  of  Panama 
fever.     The  second  regular  p  F.   T. 

Gray,  arrived  June,  1853,  and  left  in  Jun 
and  died  in  Boston  February,  1855.  The  third 
regular  pastor,  the  Rev.  R.  P.  Cutler,  arrived 
August  31,  1S5L  aud  continued  his  ministrations 
without  intermission,  until  June  1.  1859,  at 
which  time  he  resigned  his  charge,  and  left  for 
Fork.  The  Rev.  Jno.  A.  Buckingham, 
then  officiated  as  temporary  pastor  until  April, 
5,  1860.  The  present  Pastor,  Rev.  T.  S.  King, 
arrived  here  with  his  family  April  28,  I860,  and 
commenced  his  ministrations  the  following  day 


472 


SAX    FRANCISCO    DIRECTORY. 


(Sunday)  before  one  of  the  largest  congregations 
ever  assembled  in  this  city.  Since  the  com- 
mencement of  Mr.  King's  labors,  and  during  the 
period  of  ten  months  this  society  has  relieved 
:  a  debt  which  had  been  for  years  accu- 
mulating upon  them,  and  which  amounted  on 
the  1st  May.  18G0,  to  very  nearly  $20,000.  The 
mortgage  upon  the  building  $12,500  has  been 
paid,  and  the  society  is  now  entirely  free  from 
The  building  is  capable  of  seating  1,000 
persons,  and  is  one  of  the  most  attractive  places 
of  public  worship  in  the  city. 

The   original   officers   of   the   Society  were : 

F.  W.  Macondray,  Win.  Hooper,  S.  P.  Dewey, 

Jas.  King  of  Wm.,  and  F.  A.  Ifnssey,  Directors; 

9,   Clerk,  and  Jno.  Perry,  jr., 

Treasurer. 

Keen. — R.  B.  Swain.  Moderator ; 
Win.  ('.  Hinckley,  Treasurer;  W.  A.  Macondray, 
Secretary:  D.  0.  McRuer,  George  II.  Davis, 
James  Otis,  Moses  Ellis,  Wm.  Xorris  and  L.  A. 
Cooledge,  Trustees.

•iety.  has  always  been  one  of  the  largest.

The  Mariners'  Church. 
J.  Rowell,  Pas  on  Ber- 

nard Street,  near  Taylor;   Location,  Clai  . 
■  Wharf. 

church  was  organized  with  six  members, 
.  ami  now  consists  of  forty. — 
Public  worship  every  Sabbath  at  '■'■ 

i  with  the  church  a  E 
School  and   Bible  Class,   numbering  more  than 
eighty  teachers  and  scholars.    The  house  of  wor- 
ship is  a  oommodi  building,  on  Clark 

Drumtn.     1 
since  by  contributions  from  merchants  and  Other 
citizens  of  Sau  Francis* 

J,    RoWoU,    Pa-tor.  an 

lain  of  the  American  Seamen's    Friend   S 


who  has  labored  here  since  August,  1S58  ;  Obed 
Chart  and  James  F.  Stewart.  Deacons. 

This  church  finds  a  wide  field  of  usefulness, 
in  the  usual  church  services,  a  large  Bible  class 
for  seamen  and  strangers,  a  Sabbath  religious 
reading  room,  weekly  prayer  meetings,  in  sever- 
al sailors'  boarding  houses,  preaching  on  the 
Sabbath  and  personal  labor  during  the  week,  at 
the  I*.  S.  Marine  Hospital,  distribution  of  Bibles 
and  tracts  on  ship-board,  boarding  houses,  at  d 
elsewhere,  and  missionary  labors  about  the 
streets,  wharfs  and  shipping,  and  onboard  sev- 
eral men-of-war.  and  other  Bea-going  vessels. — 
It  is  an  undenominational  missionary  church. 

During  the  year  1860  a  society  was  formed 
among  the  business  men  of  San  Francisco,  hav- 
ing for  its  object  the  moral  improvement  of  sea- 
men, called  the  San  Francisco  Port  Society.  It 
seeks  to  attain  its  object  by  sustaining  the  preach- 
ing of  the  Gospel,  and  other  missionary  labors, 
in  connection  with  the  Mariners'  Church.  The 
officers  of  the  Society  for  the  present  year,  are 
H.  P.  Coon,  President  :  Ira  P.  Rankin, 
Vice  President:  J.  Powell,  Secretary;  0.  B. 
Jennings,    Treasurer;   ("apt.  J.  C.  lloyt.  Capt  J. 

P.  Thomas.  0.  P.  Jennings,  Nathaniel  Gray,  P. 
Bather,  Cyrus  Palmer,  Louis  McLane,  J.  Powell, 
and  James  F.  Stewart,  Trus-

ASSOCIATIONS  AND  SOCIETIES. 


Religious. 

CALIFORNIA  BIBLE  SOCIETY.— Organ- 
ized Oct.  30,  1849,  with  John  M.  Finley  as  Pres- 
ident, and  the  Reverends  D.  Yer  Mehr,  Albert 
"Williams,  W.  Taylor,  Yice-Presidents,  and  T.  D. 
Hunt  as  Secretary.  Meetings  of  the  Board  of 
Trustees  are  held  by  appointment  on  the  Tues- 
day after  the  first  Sunday  of  each  month.  First 
building  destroyed  by  fire,  April  26th,  1853, 
when  the  present  building  was  put  up  on  the 
same  site,  at  an  expense  of  $7,000. 

Officers— President,  Rev.  J.  T.  Peck,  D.  D. ; 
Yice-Presidents,  Revds.  A.  Williams,  D.  B. 
Cheney,  S.  H.  Willey,  S.  D.  Simonds,  F.  M.  Mc- 
Allister, J.  Rowell,  M.  C.  Briggs,  C.  C.  Pierce, 
W.  R.  Gober,  all  of  San  Francisco ;  Rev.  B.  Bri 
erly,  Nevada;  Rev.  W.  C.  Pond,  Downieville; 
Rev.  Lucius  Hamilton,  San  Jos6;  Revds.  W.  H. 
Hill  aud  J.  A.  Benton,  Sacramento ;  Rev.  J.  W. 
Ross,  Yreka ;  Hon.  D.  O.  Shattuck,  and  Hon. 
H.  P.  Coon,  San  Francisco;  Rev.  John  Braley, 
Santa  Clara;  Rev.  Isaac  Owen,  Sacramento; 
Rev.  Peter  Yeder,  Napa ;  Treasurer,  John  Mc- 
Kee;  Secretary,  Wm.  R.  Wadsworth.  Deposi- 
tory, 20  Montgomery  street ;  Rev.  F.  Buel.  agent. 

SABBATH  SCHOOL  UNION.— Re-organized 
May,  1857.  The  Union  meets  monthly,  altern- 
ately at  the  different  churches  whose  schools  are 
represented  in  the  Union,  when  reports  from  the 
different  schools,  showing  the  average  attend- 
ance of  scholars  and  teachers  for  the  previous 
month,  are  presented.     (See  General  Review.) 

Officers— President,  S.  B.  Stoddard;  Vice-

SAX  FRANCISCO  TRACT  SOCIETY— 
Auxilliary  to  American  Tract  Society ;  Deposito- 
ry at  the  Bible  House,  14  Montgomery  Street, 
near  Market.     Organized  August  16th,  1852. 

Officers — President,  A.  C.  Nichols;  Secretary, 
Thomas  B.  Ludlum;  Treasurer,  L.  P.  Fisher; 
and  a  Board  of  Directors  composed  of  one  dele- 
gate from  each  Evangelical  Church  in  the  city. 
r:  SAX  FRANCISCO  PORT  SOCIETY.— Or- 
ganized March,  1860. 

Officers — President,  H.  P.  Coon ;  Vice  Presi- 
dent, Ira  P.  Rankin;  Secretary,  J.  Rowell;  Trea- 
surer, O.  B.  Jennings;  Trustees,  J.  C.  Hoyt,  O. 
B.  Jennings,  P.  Sather,  Louis  McLane,  J.  B. 
Thomas,  Nathaniel  Gray,  Cyrus  Palmer,  J.  Row- 

35 


ell,  and  James  F.  Stewart.  The  object  of  the 
Society  is  the  moral  improvement  of  seamen,  and 
others  connected  with  the  sea,  in  this  port,  by 
aiding  the  American  Seamen's  Friend  Society  of 
New  York  in  sustaining  the  Mariners'  Church 
of  San  Francisco,  and  in  such  enterprises  con- 
nected therewith  as  the  Society  may  approve. — 
This  Society  is  organized  and  sustained  on  the 
principle,  that  it  belongs  properly  to  the  people 
of  San  Francisco  to  provide  religious  privileges 
and  instruction  for  the  Sadors  belonging  to  and 
visiting  this  port.  Any  person  may  become  a 
member  by  paying  five  dollars  a  year,  or  a  life- 
member  by  the  payment  at  one  time  of  fifty  dol- 
lars.

ORPHAN  ASYLUM,  (CATHOLIC)— Market 
near  Kearny  street.  Organized  March  23d.  is.".  1. 
and  placed  under  the  care  of  the  Sisters  of  Char- 
ity. A  frame  building  for  this  purpose  was  com- 
menced in  July,  and  completed  in  September, 
1851.  It  was  occupied  in  part  for  a  school,  and 
a  portion  was  temporarily  used  as  a  church,  un- 
der the  pastoral  charge  of  Rev.  John  Maginnis. 
The  present  capacious  brick  building  was  com- 
pleted in  November,  1854,  at  a  cost  oj  $46,000. 
It  is  a  source  of  gratification  to  behold  the  eon- 
soling  appearance  presented  by  the  275  little 
ones  now  provided  for  in  the  institution,  which 
speaks  audibly  of  the  benign  influence  of  their 
guardian  Sisters,  and  of  the  true  liberality  of  our 
community  in  their  noble  efforts  to  lend  ft  help- 
ing hand  to  the  fatherless.  Another  Spacious 
brick  binding,  of  the  same  dimensions  as  that 
erected  in  1864,  was  completed  in  January,  1859, 
for  a  school,  in  which  550  children  receive  a  use- 
ful education.  The  Asylum  is  conducted  under 
tho  sole  management  of  Archbishop  Alemany, 
Rev.  John  Maginnis  and  the  Sisters  of  Charity.

DEAF,  DUMB  AXD  BLIND  INSTITUTION. 
School,  corner  Mission  and  Sparks  streets,  or- 
ganized 1860.  Number  of  pupils,  girls  13,  boys 
15.     Total  28. 

The  Legislature  of  California,  at  its  last  ses- 
sion, made  an  appropriation  of  $10,000  for  the 
purpose  of  completing  an  additional  wing  to  the 
new  building  recently  erected  for  the  purposes 
of  this  society.  At  present  the  institution  is  un- 
der the  charge  and  control  of  the  Lady  Man- 
agers, who  are  ready  to  receive  all  children  of 
this  unfortunate  class;  and  as  the  enterprise  re- 
lies almost  entirely  upon  the  exertions  of  the 
Ladies  for  support,  it  is  hoped  that  all  will  take  an 
interest  in  it.  Among  all  the  charitable  institu- 
tions so  liberally  sustained  by  the  wealthy  and 
benevolent,  none  is  more  worthy  of  support  than 
this.  The  school  will  be  free  to  all;  yet  it  is  ex- 
pected of  parents  and  guardians  of  children,  who 
have  the  ability,  to  pay  $300  per  annum,  and  of 
those  in  moderate  circumstance,  what  they  are 
willing,  or  conveniently  can. 


The  managers  propose  to  receive  all  of  suita- 
ble age  to  commence  their  education,  and  it  is 
considered  better  to  scud  the  Deaf-Mutes  young, 
say  5  years  old,  as  it  is  essential  they  should 
learn  the  Sign  Language  correctly  at  the  com- 
mencement. 

Officers — President,  Mrs.  P.  B.  Clark;  Vice- 
President,  .Mrs.  J.  P.  Whitney;  Treasurer,  Mrs. 
B.  H.  Randolph ;  Secretary,  Mrs.  C.  W.  Jones.

tablished October,  1850,  to  assist  poor  and  needy 
Hebrews,  in  want  or  in  sickness.

cumulate as  a  sinking  fund  for  the  support  of 
widows  and  orphans.  The  society  has  a  capital

partly  on  interest.

FRENCH  BENEVOLENT  SOCIETY,  (So- 
ciete  Franchise  de  Bienfaisance  Mutuelle.) — Es- 
tablished 28th  December,  1851.  This  is  a  Mu- 
tual Relief  Society,  established  for  the  purpose 
of  affording  assistance  to  its  members  in  case  of 
sickness.  The  buildings  at  present  connected 
with  the  Society  are  located  on  the  corner  of 
Bush  and  Taylor.  A  new  and  commodious  hos- 
pital has  been  recently  erected  on  Brannan 
Street  botween  Fifth  and  Sixth,  which  forms 
a  very  important  addition  to  the  charitable  insti- 
tutions of  the  city.  Office  of  the  Society,  649 
Sacramento  Street. 

Officers. — President,  P.  Torquet;  Vice-Presi- 
dents, P.  Donnot  and  M.  Dubourque ;  Treasurer, 
E.  Lazard;  Secretaries,  Daniel  Levy  and  J.  Du- 
bourquie;  Trustees,  A.  Benard,  Dubedat,  Tre- 
ves, Franconi,  Viand.  A.  Lemaitrie,  Salamon, 
Chauche,  Peter  Job.

SAN     FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


GERMAN  GENERAL  BENEVOLENT  SO- 
CIETY OF  SAN  FRANCISCO,  (styled  in  Ger- 
man, Die  Allgemeine  Deutche  Unterstuetzungs 
Gesellschaft)  is  oue  of  the  largest  and  most  effi- 
cient charitable  associations  in  the  State.  It 
was  organized  on  the  7th  of  January,  1854,  with 
105  members,  and  has  rapidly  increased,  until 
now  it  numbers  1050  city  members  and  400  in 
the  interior. 

Only  Germans  and  persons  speaking  German 
are  admitted  to  membership.  The  chief  purpose 
of  the  association  is  mutual  assistance  iu  case  of 
sickness,  and  when  sick,  every  member  has  a 
right  to  demand  support  and  medical  attendance 
from  the  society.  The  society  has  a  second  pur- 
pose of  doing  charity  to  Germans  not  members  of 
the  association,  and  especially  to  German  immi- 
grants newly  arrived.  The  society  has  a  hospi- 
tal, situated  on  Brannan  street  near  Third,  built 
of  brick,  two  stories  high,  with  a  basement  50 
feet  by  70  on  the  ground,  fitted  up  with  steam, 
sulphur,  hot  and  cold  water  and  shower  baths, 
and  other  convenience  for  the  treatment  of  the 
sick.  The  wards  are  smaller  than  in  any  other 
hospital  in  the  city,  so  that  not  many  patients 
are  put  together  in  a  room.  The  lot  upon  which 
the  Hospital  is  built  is  137  feet  G  inches  wide  by 
275  feet  long,  the  whole  surrounded  by  a  high 
fence  and  cultivated  in  a  fine  garden,  a  part 
planted  with  ornamental  flowers  and  shrubs,  and 
part  with  kitchen  vegetables.  The  water  for  the 
Hospital  and  garden  is  supplied  by  an  artesian 
well  and  windmill.  The  property  of  the  society, 
including  the  lot  and  Hospital  building,  is  worth 
about  $29,000,  aud  the  debts  amount  to  about 
$4,500.  The  revenue  of  the  society  amounted 
in  18G0,  to  $24,131  22,  derived  chiefly  from  a 
monthh  n1  of  $1  levied  on  each  mem- 

ber. The  Hospital  cost,  in  the  year  18G<».  $16,- 
528  89.  During  1860  there  were  309  patients 
in  the  Hospital.  During  the  last  six  years  347 
persons,  non-members  of  the  association,  were 
i  in  the  Hospital  out  of  pore  charity,  and 
maintained  by  the  association  during  8,995  sick 
days  in  all,  at  an  expense  of  $16,414.  The  soci- 
ety has  as  paid  servants  in  the  Hospital,  a  super- 
intendent, an  apothecary,  a  gardener,  a  cook,  and 
three  waiters.  The  present  ollicers  of  the  Soci- 
ety an

HIBERNIAN   BOCIETY.— Thii 

..1    of  citizens  of  Irish  birth,    and  num- 


bers 50  members:  organized  February  3d,  1852. 
The  object  of  the  organization  is  to  perpetuate 
generosity  by  extending  relief  to  Irish  emigrants. 

Officers — President,  D.  J.  O'Callaghan;  Vice- 
President,  B.  Dowling;  Treasurer,  M.  Guerin; 
Secretary,  John  Callaghan.

iblished  for  the  purpose  of  affording  assist-

that  excellent  institution  to  carry  out  the  praise-

Jackson  street.

LADIES'  PROTECTION  AND  RELIEF 
SOCIETY.— Established  August  4th,  1853,  duly 
incorporated  according  to  law  Aug.  11th.  Is.",;. 
Home  and  office,  south  side  of  Tehama,  between 
First  and  Second  streets.  The  object  of  this  So- 
ciety is  to  render  protection  and  assistance  to 
Strangers,  to  sick  and  dependent  women  and 
children.  This  Society  has  under  its  supervision 
a  Home,  where  the  poor  are  sheltered  and  their 
wants  relieved.

ST.  JOSEPH'S  BENEVOLENT  SOCIETY, 
(R.  C.)— Established  1860.  The  objects  of  this 
Society  are  to  extend  assistance  to  each  other  in 
the  time  of  sickness  by  corporeal  aid  and  spiritual 
consolation ;  for  providing  their  deceased  breth- 
ren with  a  decent  and  Christian  interment  in  ac- 
cordance with  their  Holy  Faith ;  for  the  relief  of 
the  families  they  may  leave  after  them ;  as  also, 
for  stimulating  each  other  to  a  more  constant 
observance  of  the  duties  of  religion  and  the  gen- 
eral promotion  of  moral  and  intellectual  improve- 
ment. Officers — President/fhomas  Gelden ;  Vice- 
President,  Michael  Kane;  Secretary,  James  R. 
Kelly;  Treasurer,  M.  Guerin.  Meetings  held 
third  Sunday  of  each  month,  in  the  basement  of 
St.  Mary's  Cathedral.

ized 1819.  The  object  of  this  Society  is  to  sup- 
port their  siclc  countr3rmen,  and  to  procure  em- 
ployment for  those  who  are  in  want  of  it.  Offi- 
cers- President,  F.  Schulthess;  Vice  President,

Schedule  II.— Rates  of  Storage  on  Merchandise. 
Measurement  goods,  per  month.  $  I  00  per  ton  of  forty 
cubic  feet :  h-avy  ditto.  $1  00  per  ton  of  2.000  lbs;  or.  in 
either  case  the  amount  actually  paid.  The  consignees  to 
have  the  option  of  charging  by  weight  or  measurement. 
A  fraction  of  a  month  to  be  charged  as  a  month. 

Regvutioxs. — Concerning  delivery  of  Merchandise,pay" 

ment  of  freight,  etc. 

AVheu  no  express  stipulations  exist  per  bill  of  lading, 
goods  are  to  be  considered  as  deliverable  on  shore. 

Freight  on  all  goods  to  be  paid,  or  secured  to  the  satis- 
faction of  the  captain  or  consignee  of  the  vessel,  prior  to 
the  delivery  of  goods. 

After  the  delivery  to  the  purchaser  of  merchandise  sold, 

no  claims  for  damage,  deficiency  or  other  cause  shall  be 

admissible,  unless  mad.'  within  three  days,  and  no  such 

claims  shall  be  admissible  after  goods  sold  and  delivered 

left  the  city. 

When  foreign  bills  of  ladingdo  not  expressly  stipulate 
the  payment  of  freight  in  a  specific  coin,  foreign  currency 
shall  be  reckoned  according  to  the  United  States  value 
the  eof.  and  payment  may  be  made  in  any  legal  tender  of 
the  United   States. 

Wh.  re  for>  ign  bills  of  lading  expressly  stipulate  that 
the  freight  shall  be  paid  in  a  specific  coin,  then  the  same 
must  be  procured,  if  required,  or  its  equivalent  given — 
the  rate  to  be  determined  by  the  current  value  at  the 
time  in  San  Francisco. 

For  tare  on  China  sugar.  4  lbs  is  to  be  allowed  for  each 
mat  containing  4 pockets  of  about  2'>  lbs  each. 

All  other  iatesof  tare  aro  to  be  allowed  as  by  custom 
in  New  Vork,  except  when  otherwise  provided.

HIBERNIA  SAVING  AND  LOAN  SOCI- 
ETY.—Office  506  Jackson.  The  objects  for 
which  this  association  is  formed,  are,  that  by  its 
operations  the  members  thereof  may  be  enabled  to 
rind  a  secure  and  profitable  investment  for  small 
savings,  and  may  have  an  opportunity  of  obtain- 
ing from  it  the  use  of  a  moderate  capital,  on  giv- 
ing good  and  sufficient  security  for  the  payment 
of  the  same. 

Officers— President,  M.  D.  Sweeny ;  Vice-Pre- 
sident, Edward  Martin ;  Treasurer,  John  Mel ; 
Attorney,  Richard  Tobin.

SAN  FRANCISCO  ARCHITECTURAL  SO- 
CIETY.—Organized  1861.  The  object  of  the 
Society  is  to  promote  and  preserve  the  artistic, 
scientific  an  1  practical  knowledge  of  its  mem- 
bers ;  to  facilitate  their  intercourse  and  good  fel- 
lowship; to  elevate  the  standing  and  sustain  the 
dignity  of  the  sublime  profession,  and  to  unite 
the  efforts  of  those  engaged  in  the  practice  of 
Architecture,  for  the  general  advancement  of  the 
truthful  Art.  The  means  of  accomplishing  this  end 
are,  regular  meetings  of  the  members  for  the  pro- 
motion of  harmony  of  action,  the  discussion  of  sub- 
jects of  professional  importance,  the  reading  of  es- 
says and  original  papers,  lectures  on  topics  of  gen- 
eral interest,  a  library,  a  collection  of  designs  and 
models,  and  any  other  means  calculated  by  the 
Society  to  promote  the  objects  of  its  organization. 
Officers — President,  Wm.  Crane ;  Vice-President, 
Caleb  Hyatt;  Corresponding  Secretary,  Victor 
Hoffmann;  Recording  Secretary,  P.  J.  O'Conner; 
Treasurer,  Henry  Kenitzer.

Francisco,  J.  L.  Burtis ;  Santa  Cruz,  W.  N.  Slo- 
cum  ;  Monterey,  George  W.  Crane.

SAVINGS  AND  LOAN  SOCIETY— Incor- 
porated July  2Hd,  1857.  Officers— President.  Iv 
W.  Burr;  Vice-President,  John  P.  Buckley; 
Auditor.  John  Archbald ;  Secretary,  William  F. 
Herriek;  Attorney,  Giles  H.  Gray;  Surveyor, 
Gardner  Elliot. 

The  object  for  which  this  society  is  formed,  is 
that  by  means  of  it  the  members  may  lie  enabled 
to  find  a  secure  and  profitable  investment  for 
small  savings.  Deposits  received  from  two  and 
a  half  dollars  up  to  any  amount.  Deposits  are 
invested  in  mortgages  of  real  estate.  Amount 
of  capital  paid  in  nearly  s2.ooo,000,  invested  ex- 
clusively on  Brat  bond  and  mortgage.  The  Soci- 
ety havo  recently  erected  for  the  accommodation 
of  their  increasing  business  a  fine  three-story 
brick  building,  619  Clay  street.

TAX-PAYERS'  PROTECTIVE  UNION.— 
Established  March  15,  1861.  Office  611  Clay. 
The  objects  of  the  association  are  "to  promote 
an  interchange  of  views  and  sentiments  on  all 
matters  affecting  the  rights  of  Tax-Payers,  and 
to  organize  a  system  that  shall  avail  itself  of  the 
community  of  feeling  and  interest  existing  be- 
tween them,  to  secure  by  concert  of  action  an  in- 
fluence that  shall  be  powerful  to  correct  existing 
abuses,  to  frustrate  and  expose  the  schemes  of 
designing  and  unprincipled  men,  and  to  bring 
about  measures  of  public  benefit. 

Officers — President,  Lafayette  Maynard ;  Vice- 
Presidents,  R.  G.  Sneath  and  C.  J.  Dempster; 
Treasurer,  Louis  McLane;  Secretary,  Edward  R. 
Highton;  Executive  Committee,  J.  B.Thomas, 
Thomas  H.  Selby,  Myles  D.  Sweeney. 


Literary,  Historical,  etc.

SOCIETY  OF  CALIFORNIA  PIONEERS.— 
Rooms,  Pioneer  Hall,  70-1  Washington  near 
Kearny.  Organized  in  August,  1850.  Stated 
meetings  first  Tuesday  in  each  month,  officers — 
For  the  year  commencing  July  7th,  1861.  Presi- 
dent, Henry    M.    Cray,    M.  D. ;    Vice-Presidents, 

Willard  li.  Farwell,  of  San  Francisco,  James 
Donahue,  and  Henry  F.  "Williams,  of  San  Fran- 
cisco; James  Lick,  of  Santa  Clara:  ( ieorge  C. 
Yount,  of  Napa;  Levi  Hitc,  of  Marysville :  Sec- 
retary, William  R.  Wheaton ;  Treasurer,  John 
II.  Turncy;  Directors,  W.  A.  Macondrav.  Jos. 
C.  Vandervoort.  James  Pullman,  J.  H.  Widber, 
P.  R.  Cornwall,  D.  J.  Oliver,  Edward  Hall.  The 
President,  Secretary  and  Treasurer,  are  r.r -officio 

members  of  the  Hoard  of  Directors,  and  Trustees 

of  tlio  Society.    The  expressed  objects  of  the 

Society  aro  to  collect  and  preserve  information 
connected  with  the  early  settlement  and  subse- 
quent conquest  of  the  country,  and  to  perpetu- 
ate the  memory  of  those  whose  sagacity,  energy 

and  enterprise  induced  them  to  settle  in  the  wil- 
derness and  become  the  founders  of  a  new  State. 

All  who  were  iii  California  prior  to  the  first  day 
of  January,  L850,  are  eligible  to  membership. 
Any    who  may    have  rendered   distinguished   or 

important  services  to  the  Society,  the  state,  or 

the  United  States,  may  be  admitted  as  honorary 

members.     At  this  date  the  roll  of  the  Society 

embraces  the  names  of  836  members.      Regular 

-  of  the  Society    take    place    on  the    first 

Monday  of  each  month.      Annual  election  ofofflw

HEBREW  YOUNG  MEN'S  LITERARY 
ASSOCIATION.— Rooms,  225  Minna.  Organi- 
zed October,  1854;  re-organized  October,  1855. 
Number  of  members,  147.  Number  of  volumes 
in  the  library,  1,200,  exclusive  of  full  files  of  city 
and  the  leading  Atlantic  and  European  papers. 
Business  meetings  are  held  monthly.  Trustee 
meetings,  third  Tuesday  in  each  month.  Lite- 
rary exercise  meetings  every  other  Sunday  eve- 
ning; rooms  open  every  evening.  Officers — 
President,  Bernard  Simon;  Vice-President,  Laz- 
arus Schuartz ;  Recording  Secretary.  Silas  Solo- 
mon :  Financial  Secretary,  Nathan  Meyer ;  Treas- 
urer, Emanuel  Levy ;  Librarian,  B.  E.  Van  Stat-

ris Crown. 

MECHANICS'  INSTITUTE.  —  Organized 
March  29,  1855.  Rooms,  314  Montgomery  street 
second  floor.  The  objects  of  the  Institute  are 
the  establishment  of  a  library,  reading-room,  col- 
lection of  a  cabinet,  scientific  apparatus,  works 
of  art,  and  other  literary  and  scientific  purposes. 
The  Society  has  a  reading-room  well  supplied 
with  the  leading  scientific  and  literary  periodi- 
cals of  the  day,  and  a  valuable  library  containing 
over  4.500  volumes.  During  the  year  1858  and 
1860,  this  Institute  presented  to  the  attention  of 
the  people  of  California  their  second  and  third 
annual  exhibitions,  which  were  attended  with  the 
most  complete  success. 

Officers — President,  John  P.  Buckley;  Vice- 
President,  "Wm.  McKibbin ;  Recording  Secretary. 
P.  B.  Dexter;  Corresponding  Secretary,  J.  A. 
Magagnos;  Treasurer,  John  E.  Kincaid ;  Direc- 
tors, John  R.  Sims,  C.  M.  Plum,  Paul  Torquet, 
G.  W.  Gilmore,  Aaron  Doud,  Frank  Eastman, 
Nathan  Porter. 

MERCANTILE  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION. 
— Mercantile  Library  Buildings,  NE  corner  Mont- 
gomery and  Bush.  Organized  January  24th, 
1853,  by  the  election  ofD.  S.  Turner,  President; 
Joshua  P.  Haven,  Vice-President;  C.  E.  Bowers, 
Treasurer ;  W.  H.  Stevens,  Recording  Secreta- 
ry; Dr.  Henry  Gibbons,  Corresponding  Secreta- 
ry; and  Messrs.  E.  P.  Flint,  E.  E.  Dunbar,  D. 
H.  Haskell  and  J.  B.  Crockett,  Directors. 

Officers,  January  2\st,  1 86 1-— President,  Jas. 


W.  White;  Vice-President,  Thos.  J.  Lamb; 
Treasurer,  Benj.  Smith;  Recording  Secretary, 
E.  H.  Jacquelin;  Corresponding  Secretary,  Wal- 
ter Martineau ;  Directors,  Maj.  H.  Leonard,  A. 
L.  Edwards,  John  S.  Davies,  J.  P.  Nourse,  R.  C. 
Rogers,  J.  Lawrence  Pool,  J.  M.  Strobridge,  J. 
C.  Johnson,  J.  M.  McNulty,  M.  D. 

The  Mercantile  Library  Association  has  been 
most  carefully  and  ably  conducted,  and  most 
generously  sustained  by  the  citizens  of  San  Fran- 
cisco; and  from  the  progress  it  has  made  during 
the  past  few  years,  it  must  soon  take  rank  with 
its  kindred  institutions  in  the  Eastern  States. — 
The  library  of  the  association  is  the  first  in  the 
State,  numbering  over  15,000  volumes  of  works 
in  the  different  departments  of  literature.  Con- 
nected with  the  library  is  a  valuable  and  exten- 
sive collection  of  works  of  reference,  4,000  vol- 
umes in  extent,  which  is  open  to  the  inspection 
of  visitors  and  the  public  in  general.  The  amount 
expended  for  books,  etc.,  for  increase  of  library, 
during  the  last  fiscal  year,  was  $4,000  ;  increase 
of  library  during  same  period,  2,500  volumes. 

The  new  rooms  of  the  Association  arc  commo- 
dious and  conveniently  arranged,  and  are  well 
adapted  to  meet  the  growing  importance  of  the 
institution.  A  well  selected  assortment  of  the 
leading  newspapers  and  periodicals  of  the  United 
States  and  Europe,  are  contained  therein  ;  and 
in  addition  thereto,  a  cabinet  of  specimens  of 
mineralogy  and  the  natural  history  of  the  State, 
and  a  numerous  and  valuable  collection  of  paint- 
ings, engravings  etc.  Number  of  members, 
1,800;  average  number  of  volumes  taken  out 
monthly,  2,800.  The  terms  of  admission  to  the 
rooms  and  library  are  $2  initiation  fee,  and  $1 
per  month,  payable  quarterly.  The  influence  of 
an  institution  of  this  character,  properly  direct- 
ed, cannot  be  estimated ;  and  it  can  scarcely  be 
doubted  that  the  esprit  du  corps  of  the  merctn- 
tile  community  of  this  city  will  sustain  and  en- 
large this  association,  by  confiding  its  manage- 
ment to  energetic  and  talented  men,  and  by  lib- 
erally contributing  to  its  support.  Librarian,  H. 
H.  Moore ;  Assistants,  D.  E.  Webb  and  H.  T. 
Burr ;  Collector,  John  J  Tayker. 

MERCHANTS'  EXCHANGE.— Theodore  E. 
Baugh,  proprietor,  521  Clav,  S  side,  bet  Sansom 
and  Montgomery.  The  Merchants'  Exchange 
was  opened  by  Messrs.  Sweeny  &  Baugh,  in 
March,  1852,  on  Sacramento  street,  one  square 
south  of  its  present  location,  and  in  September, 
1853,  they  completed  a  line  of  telegraph  to  Point 
Lobos  (south  head)  enabling  them  to  report  as 
soon  as  they  could  be  signalized  at  sea,  the  names 
of  inward-bound  vessels.  The  Telegraph  Line  is 
the  pioneer  on  the  Pacifio  coast.  In  July,  1855, 
the  Exchange  was  located  in  its  present  commo- 
dious rooms,  where  can  be  found  files  of  the 
leading  newspapers,  foreign  and  domestic. 

ODD  FELLOWS'  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION. 
— Organized  1855.  Rooms,  NE  corner  Kearny 
and  Bush.  Officers — President,  S.  H.  Parker; 
1st  Vice-President,  Henry  Kimball;  2d  Vice- 
President,  Henry  C.  Squires ;  Secretary,  A.  Him. 
melmann;  Treasurer,  A.  Himmclmann;  Libra, 
rian,  John  Southwell ;  Board   of  Directors,  Jo. 


482 


SAN      FRANCISCO      DIRECTORY 


seph  Mayer,  Henry  B.  Brooks,  J.  A.  J.  Bohen, 
W.  H.  Satterlee,  John  Pliillips,  Julius  Adler, 
Philo  White,  Henry  Friedel,  John  Pforr. 

This  library  now  contains  7.000  volumes  of 
standard  and  other  books,  including  a  very  valu- 
able collection  of  rare  and  antique  works,  and 
the  most  complete  series  on  the  early  history  of 
the  Pacific  coasts  to  be  found  in  California.  The  j 
Association  also  own  a  valuable  museum.

Hook  and  Ladder  Co.  No.  1.  Oncers— President,

ST.  MARY'S  LIBRARY  ASSOCIATION— 
Organized  1855.  Rooms  basement  St.  Mary's 
Cathedral.  This  Association  has  a  valuable  and 
well-selected  library  of  about  800  volumes,  the 
advantages  of  which  may  be  secured  by  those 
desirous  of  becoming  active  members  on  payment 
of  the  entrance  fee  of  one  dollar,  and  a  monthly 
subscription  of  fifty  cents.  Subscribing  mem- 
bers are  admitted  on  the  payment  of  fifty  cents 
and  a  monthly  assessment  of  twenty-five  cents. 
icbed  to  this  library,  a  valuable  col- 
lection of  Manuscript  Letters  of  the  old  Spanish 
Missionaries,  relating  to  the  early  history  of  the 
Missions  of  Upper  and  Lower  California,  dating 
from  the  middle  of  the  last  century.  The  Libra- 
ry room  is  open  every  Sunday  afternoon  for  the 
reception  of  visitors  and  persons  desirous  of  be- 
coming members,  and  on  Thursday  evenings. — 
Regular  monthly  meetings  first  Monday  of  each 
mouth.

dcui.  Wm.  II.  Ash;  Recording  Secretary,  T.  J. 
Gallagher;  Corresponding  Secretary,  John  P. 
Carroll;  Treasurer,  M.  Flood;  Librarian,  P.  Cum- 
mings.

TURN  VEREIN—  Organized  1853.  Rooms, 
SW  corner  California  and  Kearny.  Stated  meet- 
ings first  and  third  Thursday  evening  of  each 
month.  The  object  of  this  Society  is  to  main- 
tain liberal  political  and  religious  principles,  to 
encourage  morality,  to  improve  health  and  culti- 
vate music.  Number  of  members,  80,  of  which 
about  30  are  attached  to  the  vocal  department.

er, Jacob  Knejl

P. -.Jesse  Morrill.  G.  Sentinel,  Sacramento.

which  number,  one  is  located  in  this  city,  viz:

ner of  Washington  and  Kearny  streets.  Officers

W.  Bourne,  Recorder;  Lewis  Peck,  Sentinel. 
114  members.

Indep't  Order  of  Knighthood. 

This  Charitable  and  Benevolent  institution  is 
of  purely  California  origin,  being  first  organized 
at  Folsora,  October  16th,  1858. 

There  is  in  this  State  at  the  present  time  a 
Grand  Supreme  Council  of  the  United  States,  a 
Grand  Camp  of  the  State  of  California,  and  33 
Subordinate  Camps,  all  in  good  flourishing  con- 
dition. 

Officers  of  Supreme  Council — Geo.  Johnson, 
M.  W.  R.,  Volcano;  H.  B.  Meredith,  If.  W.  D'y 
R.,  Folsom;  S.  W.  Prothero,  M.  W.  Sec'y,  Mich- 
igan Bar;  G.  W.  Bond,  M.  W.  P.;  C.  Hall.  M. 
W.  H.:  H.  G.  A.  Struve,  M.  W.  W.j  J.  A.  Ash- 
baugh,  M.  W.  G. 

Officers  of  the  Grand  Camp — P.  B.  Denny,  G. 
R.;  S.  W.  Prothero,  G.  D.  R.;  H.  II.  Fellows, 
G.  Sec'y;  J.  F.  Brown,  G.  T.;  T.  W.  Xve.  G. 
M.;  Vince  Michaels,  G.  P.;  H.  F.  Lear,  G.  W.; 
S.  C.  Hodges,  G.  S.

tery.— Organized  July  27,  1849.  Number  of

AY  ELLS,  FAR  <0  &  CO.— This  is  a  joint  stock 
company,  with  a  capital  of  $1,000,000.  Princi- 
pal office,  in  New  York,  at  84  Broadway.  Pres- 
ident. D.N.  Barney;  Treasurer,  C.  F.  Latham ; 
General  Agent,  Louis  McLane,  Jr. ;  Superinten- 
dent Express  and  Banking  Departments,  Samuel 
Knight.  Principal  office  in  California,  in  Par- 
rott's  Building,  corner  Montgomery  and  Califor- 
nia streets.  This  company  has  branch  express 
offices  in  all  the  principal  cities  and  towns  in  Cal- 
ifornia and  Oregon,  and  banking  offices  at  Sacra- 
mento and  Stockton,  Cal.,  Portland,  Oregon,  and 
Victoria,  V.  I.,  connecting  in  their  express  busi- 
ness with  all  the  principal  express  companies  in 
the  Atlantic  States  and  Europe.  Established 
branch  in  California,  July  13,  1852.

CALIFORNIA  STATE  TELEGRAPH  CO.— 
Reincorporated,  1861.  Capital  stock.  $1,250,000. 
Officers — H.  W.  Carpentier,  President ;  J.  Mora 
Moss,  Daniel  S.  Roberts,  R.  E.  Brewster,  J.  M. 
McDonald,  Board  of  Directors;  E.  S.  Miller, 
Secretary;  R.  E.  Brewster,  Treasurer;  James 
Gamble,  General  Superintendent;  George  S. 
Ladd,  Assisting  Superintendent.  Office,  No. 
630  Montgomery  street,  in  Montgomery  Block. 
Office  hours  from  8  o'clock,  A.  M.,  to  9  o'clock, 
P.  M.  Sun-Jay,  from  9  to  11  o'clock,  A.  M., 
and  from  6  to  8  o'clock,  P.  M.  This  line  ex- 
tends to  the  following  cities  and  towns,  viz.:  San 
Francisco,  Sacramento,  Marysville,  Placerville, 
San  Jose,  Stockton,  Coloma,  Auburn,  Grass  Val- 
ley, Nevada,  San  Juan  North,  Camptonville,  For- 
est City.  Downieville,  Folsom.  El  Dorado,  Dia- 
mond Springs,  Volcano,  Jackson,  Mokelumne 
Hill,  San  Andreas,  Murphy's  Camp,  Columbia,

Santa  Clara,  San  Leandro,  Oakland,  Warm 
Springs,  San  Mateo,  Martinez.  Benicia,  Suisun, 
Oroville,  Chico,  Tehama,  Red  Blufi',  Shasta, 
Weaverville,  Callaghan's  Ranch,  Yreka,  Straw- 
berry Valley,  Genoa,  Carson  City,  Virginia  City, 
Silver  City,  Fort  Churchill,  Gilroy,  San  Juan 
South,  Fresno,  Visalia,  Fort  Tejon,  Los  Angeles 
and  connecting  with  Georgetown,  Yankee  Jim's,
