BRITISH  HOSPITAL.— This  institution  has 
been  discontinued,  and  an  arrangement  made 
with  the  city  to  provide  for  the  indigent  sick  of 
the  British  association. 

COUNTY  HOSPITAL.— SW  corner  Francisco 
and  Stockton.  Resident  Physician,  Charles  H. 
Raymond,  M.  D. ;  Visiting  Surgeon,  F.  A.  Hol- 
man,  M.  D. ;  Visiting  Physician,  S.  R.  Gerry,  M. 
D. ;  M.  C.  Bateman,  contractor  for  Diet,  etc. — 
Average  number  of  patients,  176;  daily  admis- 
sions, 3.  Deaths  about  10  per  cent,  per  annum. 
The  situation  of  the  building  occupied  by  the 
Hospital  is  salubrious  and  beautiful — on  the 
shore  of  the  North  Beach,  commanding  an  ex- 
tensive view  of  the  Bay,  immediately  opposite 
Alcatraces  and  Angel  Islands,  with  the  village  of 
Saucelito  and  the  picturesque  headlands  of  Marin 
County  in  the  distance.  The  structure  is  of  brick, 
and,  with  the  recent  additions,  capable  of  accom- 
modating 200  patients.  The  present  charge  on 
our  citizens  for  all  purposes  connected  with  the 
care  and  maintenance  of  the  indigent  sick  is  but 
$3,000  per  month,  as  compared  with  $16,143, 
the  average  monthly  expenditure  for  the  three 
years  prior  to  the  consolidation  of  the  Govern- 
ments of  the  City  and  County.  In  addition  to 
those  within  the  Hospital,  there  is  an  average  of 
500  outside  patients  yearly. 

FRENCH  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the 
French  Benevolent  Society;  Fifth  and  Sixth. 
(See  Benevolent  Associations.) 

GERMAN  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the 
German  Benevolent  Society ;  Branuau  and  Third. 
(See  Benevolent  Associations.) 

ITALIAN  HOSPITAL.— Sustained  by  the 
Italian  Mutual  Benevolent  Society.  (See  Benev- 
olent Associations.)

SAN"     FRANCISCO     DIRECTORY. 


HOSPITAL  OF  THE  SISTERS  OF  MERCY. 
Marine  Hospital  )  No.  1316  Stock- 
ton Street,  bet  Broadway  and  Yallejo  Streets. 
Attending  Physicians,  Prs.  A.  J.  Bowie  and  J. 
P.  Whitney;  Apothecary,  Patrick  Byrne; 
ard.  J.  Kelly.  The  religions  Bisterhood  attend 
the  patients  in  person;  they  number  28,  who  are 
distributed  about  the  various  duties  of  the  hos- 
pital, some  as  nurses,  others  attending  the  de- 
partments of  cooking,  washing,  etc.  A  new  and 
commodious  brick  edifice,  situated  on  the  corner 
of  First  and  Bryant  Streets,  is  now  being  conf- 
pleted  for  the  purposes  of  the  religious  sisterhood 
connected  with  this  institution,  which  will  be 
reauy  lor  occupation  by  November  next.  Aver- 
age number  of  patients,  35  per  month ;  deaths, 
per  month,  1.

AT  THE  SUGGESTION  OF  NUMEROUS  MEMBERS  OF  THE  MEDICAL  PROFESSION 
the  undersigned  has  opened  the  above  Establishment  for  the  the  treatment  of  various  diseases 
in  which  he  lias  been 

^33Sd:i2srE]srTiL."5r  stjooessful. 

In  directing  attention  to  the  ECLECTIC  INSTITUTE  the  undersigned  would  simply  state  that 
he  has  devot^  much  time,  during  the  last  fifteen  years,  to  the  study  of  Electricity,  and  for  the  past 
five  years,  he  has  applied  it  for  medical  purposes,  with  such  success  as  to  warrant  him  in  feeling 
confident  that  he  can  do  justice  to  any  case  that  may  be  intrusted  to  his  care.  For  the  efficacy  of 
his  treatment  .references  can  be  made  to  the  most  responsible  parties,  in  this  city,  and  throughout 
the  State  who  have  been  cured  of  the  worst  maladies  by  its  application. 

flg^~  Phys'  ians  wishing  to  send  their  patients  to  this  establishment  may  be  assured  that  they 
will  be  treated  in  strict  accordance  with  their  directions. 


The  Institute  has  beeen  appropriately  and  conveniently  fitted  up  and 
IS  INTOW  OPEN  for  the  RECEPTION  ofPATIENTS.

The  amount  of  the  Capital  of  this  Company,  viz.,  Ten  Millions  of  Dollars, 
which  would  be  immediately  available  to  meet  any  unforseen  calamity,  the  well-known 
character  of  its  Directors,  the  high  respectability  of  its  Proprietors,  and  the  standing 
which  it  takes  among  the  large  Insurance  Establishments,  enable  it  to  rank  with  the 
most  eligible  offices  now  in  existence,  either  in  Europe  or  America,  with  respect  to 
the  advantages  offered  to  the  Public.

ADVERTISING     DEPARTMENT. 


523 


MimW  FOUNDRY  AND  MAGBINS  WORM 

FIRST  STREET,  between  Howard  and  Folsom, 


HOWLAND,  ANGELL  &  KING, 

MANUFACTURERS    OF 

Steam  Engines,  Mill  and  Quartz  Mill  Machinery 

AND  IRON   CASTINGS,  OF  ALL  KINDS. 

.  ♦  • 

JBf-  This  Establishment,  as  its  name  imports,  is  essentially  FOR  THE  MIXES.  The  Proprie- 
tors have  been  engaged  for  the  past  Eight  Years  in  Manufacturing  MINING  MACHINERY  and 
Putting  Up  QUARTZ  MILLS,  and  have  PATTERNS  for  all  kinds  of  STRAIGHT  and  ROTAR1 
BATTERIES,  and  AMALGAMATORS,  for  both  Gold  and  Silver.  Having  for  the  past  two  years 
paid  particular  attention  to  this  branch,  which  is  the  great  want  of  the  country,  and  have  Patterns 
for  all  the  different  PANS  in  use— several  that  are  adapted  to,  and  used  by,  the  various  New 
Processes  for  Extracting  Silver  speedily. 

STEAM  ENGINES,  Gearing  of  all  descriptions,  Car  "Wheels,  Water 
Wheel  Castings,  Flouring  Mill  Machinery,  Saw  Mills,  Mining  Pumps, 
Quartz  Mill  Screws,  Stamp  Shoes,  and  Dies  of  WHITE  IRON— in  short, 
CASTINGS  AND  MACHINERY  OF  EVERY  DESCRIPTION! 

To  persona  wanting  Machinery,  or  desiring  information  in  regard  to  anything  in  our  line,  we  will,  on  application, 
by  letter  or  otherwise,  send  our  PATTERN"    LIST,  aud  answer  any  inquiries.

FIRST  STREET,  NEAR  GAS  WORKS. 


Iron  Founders  and  Steam  Engrine  Builders. 


The  Machine  Shop  possesses  the  greatest  number  and  the  largest  dimensions  of 
Tools  in  the  State.  They  have  Lathes  to  turn  nine  feet  in  diameter  and  thirty  feet 
long.  Their  other  facilities  for  executing  work  rapidly  and  efficiently  are  unsurpassed. 
Upwards  of  300  Steam  Engines  made  at  their  own  Works,  are  now  running 
in  this  State  and  Oregon,  in  Steamboats,  Quartz  Mills,  Saw  and  Flouring  Mills. 

Their  Boiler  Works  have  turned  out  upwards  of  600  Steam  Boilers 

of  all  kinds.

As  Manilla  or  Hemp  Rope,  of  equal  strength,  and  is  unaffected  by  changa  of  "Weather. 

It  is  more  particularly  adapted  for  DERRICK  GUY  ROPES,  FERRY  ROPES,  and  for  hoist- 
ing from  deep  Shafts  and  Inclined  Planes.  Mining  Companies  and  Ferry  owners,  who  use  rope 
for  Winding,  Hoisting  or  Standing  purposes,  will  effect  an  immense  saving  by  ordering  WIRE 
ROPE,  through  our  Agents.

Oroville,  Butte  County,  February,  1861. 
Messrs.  A.  S.  Hallibie  &  Co.,  Wirr  Rape  Mamifartnrers  : 

GfnTS  _l  have  thoroughly  tested  the  Wire  Rope  vou  put  on  ray  Ferry,  and  to  my  entire  satisfaction.  After  the  wear  and 
tear'ofuearlv  two  seasons  I  Judge  it  to  be  as  good  aa  when  put  up.  I  run  the  Ferry  at  all  stages  of  water,  when  others  are  com- 
pelled to  stand  still      On  one  occasion,  by  a  sudden  rise  of  the  river,  an  immense  hoom  used  for  collecting  saw  logs,  and  an  accu- 


Jl  lea  10  MitlKl  till  I.        \Jll  Wile  «\.t,no'"ii,     '-V    «■  «««*■•-•>   •  ■  •-—  v    »..-.....•,.. < ■  -  -■     ■    .         ,  r   «* 

inlation  of  logs,  became  fastened  on  the  Wire  Rope,  carrying  away  the  fastenings  on  one  side,  but  the  rope  remained  perfect. 

,H  use  soft  brass  sheaves,  and  the  boat  travels  across  i '  

Ferry  puiposes— being  satisfied  that  it  is  cheaper,  safer, 


We 'use  soft  brass  sheaves,  and  the  boat  travels  across  very'  smoothly.     I  can  strongly  recommend  the  use  of  the  Wire  Rope  for

to  incompetent  workmen.  *.J.  McG.  is  prepared  to  readjust  and  repair,  in  first  rate 
style,  all  Chronometers  and  1'iue  Watches  put  into  his  hands.

OPPOSITE  THE  PACIFIC  MAIL  STEAMSHIP  COMPANY'S  OFFICE, 


Established  in  1854,  for  the  Penransnt  Cure  of  all  Private  and  Chronic  Diseases, 
and  for  tie  sippression  of  Quackery. 

Attending  and  Resident  Physician— L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  M.  D., 

Late  in  the  Hungarian  Revolutionary  War,  Chief  Physician  to  the  20th  Regi- 
ment of  Honveds,  Chief  Surgeon  of  the  Military  Hospital  at  Pesth,  Hun- 
gary, late  Lecturer  on  Diseases  of  Genito-Uriuary  Organs,  and  Dis- 
eases of  Women  and  Children,  and  Honorary  member  of  the 
Philadelphia  College  of  Medicine,  Etc. 

Particular  attention  paid  to  the  treatment  of  Diseases  peculiar  to  Women  &  Children. 

OFFICE  HOURS-From  O  A.  IM.  to   O  I?.  M. 

£W  Communications  strictly  confidential.     Permanent  cure  guaranteed,  or  no  pay.     Consulta- 
tions (by  letter  or  otherwise)  FREE.  Address, 

Dr.  L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  San  Francisco. 


SpermatorrliGea 

Or  local  weakness,  nervous  debility,  low  spirits,  lassitude,  weakness  of  the  limbs  and  back,  indis- 
position and  incapability  for  labor  and  study,  dullness  of  apprehension,  loss  of  memory,  aversion  to 
society,  love  of  solitude,  timidity,  self-distrust,  dizziness,  headache,  involuntary  discharges,  pains  in 
the  side,  affections  in  the  eye,  pimples  on  the  face,  sexual  or  other  infirmities  in  man,  are  cured  by 
the  justly  celebrated  physician  and  surgeon,  L.  J.  CZAPKAY.  His  method  of  curing  diseases 
is  new,  (unknown  to  others),  and  hence  the  great  success.  All  consultations,  by  letter  or  other- 
wise, Free.  |y  Address,  L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  M.  D.,  San"  Francisco. 

TO  CORRESPONDENTS  : 
Patients  residing  in  any  part  of  the  State,  however  distant,  who  may  desire  the  opinion  and  advice  of  DR.  CZAP- 
KAY on  their  respective  cases,  and  who  think  proper  to  submit  a  written  .statement  of  such,  in  preference,  to  holding 
a  personal  interview,  are  respectfully  assured  that  their  communications  will  he  held  must  Mend.  ML  CZAPKAY 
takes  this  opportunity  of  observing  that  all  letters  arc  only  opened  and  replied  to  by  himself,  and  the  latter  as  prompt- 
ly as  possible  If  the  case  be  fully  and  candidly  described,  pel sonal  communication  will  be  superseded,  as  instruc- 
tions for  diet,  regimen,  and  the  genera]  treatment  of  the  ease  itself  |  Including  the  remedies  >  will  be  forwarded  without 
delay,  and  in  such  a  manner  as  to  convey  do  idea  of  the  purport  of  the  letter  or  parcel  so  transmitted.  Permanent 
core  guaranteed  or  no  pay.    Consultations  Uratis.  L.  J.  CZAPKAY,  M.  D.,  San  Francisco,  Cal.

No.  412  MONTGOMERY  STREET,  San  Francisco. 


570 


SAN    FRANCISCO    DIRECTORY. 


J8^»This,  the  most  extensive  MARKET,  and  one  of  the  features  of  our  com- 
mercial metropolis,  is  located  in  the  immediate  vicinity  of  the  great  thoroughfare, 
MONTGOMERY  STREET.  It  can  be  approached  from  Washington,  Sansora  and 
Merchant  Streets,  upon  which  it  has  a  frontage  of  95,  80  and  171|  feet  respectively, 
with  a  depth  of  120  feet.  Few  enterprises  in  San  Francisco  have  been  conducted 
with  greater  success  than  this  Market,  and  its  popularity  must  continue  to  increase 
so  long  as  its  management  is  intrusted  to  the  same  energetic  and  enterprising  gen- 
tlemen who  have  so  ably  conducted  it  from  its  first  opening  to  the  present  time. 

E.  JACOB  CHASE,  PAGE,  WILLIAMS  &  CO., 

Superintendent.  Proprietors.

THIS   HALL, 

SSI  E^MISS  AST®  S'JISJIBS'ff  W  ffiEffl  Sf  4^S9 

HAS  JUST  BEEN  ERECTED  ON 

Montgomery  Street,  near  Bush. 

It  is  on  the  ground  floor,  is  built  of  brick,  and  entirely  fire-proof. 
All  modern  Improvements  have  been  adopted  in  its  Construction. 

jt  h  iltmwujlttii  tatlaid  &  Stated 

From  the  Ceiling  in  the  same  manner,  as  the  U.  S.  Senate  Chamber. 

THE  SEATS  HAVE  SPRING  BOTTOMS, 

Thus  doubling  the  space  available  to  an  audience  when  entering  or  leaving  the  Hall. 

Equal  to  one  space  of  Forty-Five  Feet. 
B@~  Under  the  Hall,  and  connected  with  it,  is 

A.  Large  Dining  Room 

75  by  100  feet,  with 

PARLORS,  DRESSING  ROOMS,  KITCHEN,  BAKER'S  OVEN, 

AND  EVERY  CONVENIENCE   ATTACHED. 
ADJOINING  THE  LARGE  IIALL  IS  A 

SOCIAL  HALL  FOE  PRIVATE  PAETIES  and  SOCIAL  GATHERINGS, 

Capable  of  accomodating  300  Persons. 


'  Acoustic  effect  has  been  especially  studied  in  the  construction  of  the  Hall,  and  in  everyre- 
spect  it  is  fully  adapted  to  every  use  which  can  be  made  of  a  Public  Hall,  for  large 

^yEEEXIKTGf-S,  LECTURES,  PARTIES, 

CONCERTS,  OPERAS,  ETC.,   ETC.
